review_title: Great company, but some positions require lots of hours with a non-existent work/life balance.
pros: Bank of America is a very stable and huge company that can offer a great deal of opportunities and flexibility in one's schedule.  This company has many great opportunities to transfer to different positions and become involved in various aspects of the banking industry.  Bank of America also offers great benefits to its associates.  For a while they were offering stock options in a program called "Take Ownership" for employees at a certain level within the company.  This program allowed associates to receive a number of stock options for a few years.  Although the program was discontinued, while in place, it allowed those employees receiving it to receive a nice bonus when the options were exercised--especially if you exercised them at the right time.
cons: One of the main downsides of working at Bank of America, especially in my capacity, as a commissioned employee in the appraisal department, there wasn't much work/life balance.  We received work 24 hours 7days a week, including holidays.  Unfortunately this did not allow appraisers to much time to spend with family on a regular basis.  This occurred nationwide within the company and most appraisers felt that they didn't ever have any free time because they were always working.  Once BofA went to a 24 hours/7days a week clock, appraisers had to work excessive hours and had to work every day of the week.

review_title: As long as you are able to get along with everyone in your branch it is a wonderful company to work for
pros: Great benefits package for part time employees they also offer an excellent tuition reimbursement program that I have found to much be better than the leading competition. They reimbursed me for over 7,000 worth of tuition costs only working 20 hours a week and when I left two years later they did not require me to pay it back.
cons: Really poor management - associate connection

review_title: Not a good place to build a career - too much change- and no focus on the associate- sink or swim mentality
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros:
-great place to learn if you are right out of school
-base pay was good (many people are underpayed, however compared to other industries the base pay is great
cons:
-promotion and career advancement are based on who you know not your performance
-company reorganizes at least every 6 months- so few opportunities to actually see your work through completion or know if it was successfully implemented
-company does not acknowledge the cultural differences between itself and the companies it acquires - company did a culture assessment with Merrill Lynch, but would not release the results (and the cultural fit was a big reason why so many from MBNA left after the BAC acquisition)
-amazing company is still up and running after so many acquisitions- everything on the back-end is bandaided together- business has a hard time focused on innovative work because so much time has to be spent on just getting the systems to continue to function
-management and leadership skills are severly lacking- BAC promotes people into people manager roles who have no training or capabilities to lead - which has resulted in many people leaving the company
-worst handling i have seen of severances- did not give associates across the bank any time frame when they would know whether or not they had a job- so each week you would hear of associates in other areas who got let go- and not know when your time was coming
-not a great place to be right now because there will be so much more change happening after Ken retires- so enter at your own risk knowing things will be in flux for a while

review_title: The most BS job I have ever had.
pros: The benefits are awesome! You do get benefits if you are full or part time. They do have a good tuition reimbursement program of $5200 a year.
cons:
The many BS of this jobs are as follows:
- hard to move up. I been working there as a teller for 3 1/2 yrs and I'm still a stupid teller. I have seen people in my same branch that have worked for a year or less get moved up. When I ask about promotions they say there is none. EX: A guy at another branch I know has been working for 1 yr and got "promoted" to a senior teller. I ask my manager if I can get "promoted" to a senior teller and they said I haven't worked long enough.
- you deal with a lot of stress....people with constantly yell at you because everyone in the world thinks they know more about the banking business than its own employees. Grown people carry $2 in their accounts and expect to be treated like kings and queens to keep their business.
- its a sales job. you are constantly pounded on meeting sales goals. yes, i know its part of the job, but even once your past your goal they dont think its enough and push you for more. it just never ends.
- if you speak spanish, you got a job. they barely interview you. i have seen 2 better candidates over looked because they didnt speak spanish, and they hired the bi-lingual. (sorry im not being a racist if it comes out that way, i just think that they should look at qualifications and not just if you speak spanish)

review_title: Risk Management Analyst withing one of the major lines of business.
job_title: Risk Management Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros:
1. Opportunity to work for a major player in the banking industry
2. Ability to have several different careers, and in different geographical locations, over a period of time while still working for the same parent company.  
3. Management is very open to employees moving to other roles after working in your current role for 2 years or so (assuming you at least meet expectations).  
4. You have access to all of the analytical software tools you need to get the job done.  They also provide you free training on the most popular tools if necessary for your job (great for future career advancement and resume padding!).
5. Good total compensation and benefits
6. We have a new CEO with new and different ideas as to how to run the company
cons:
1. Red tape.  Often difficult to get things done when you need information from several people in different parts of the company and country.
2. Banking can get boring.  Cranking out spreadsheets and reviewing numbers and dollars can only stimulate you for so long.  
3. You can often be so buried in the bowels of the business that you don't get to see the big picture reasons behind why your work is important and how it impacts the business and the bottom line.  Makes you want to work for a smaller company at times.
4. Business leaders can sometimes focus on the revenue numbers and ignore net income.  This caused some of the financial catastrophe we've seen over the past 2 years.  However, this has changed given the fallout of the mortgage crisis.  The Risk team now has much more veto power than ever before.  Risk is now a force to be reckoned with within the company.

review_title: Bank of America - place to work
pros:
-excellent 401k opportunities, matches up to 5%
-great healthcare benefits
-tuition reimbursement available
-overtime and incentive is available in some departments
cons:
-salary is not comparable to what other companies are offering doing same job

job_title: Product Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Very nice group of people
Company has warm, supportive culture in terms of recognizing hard work and effort 
Try to be fair with raises and bonuses
cons: Way too many meetings with too many people involved - a real time waster. Nobody is empowered to make decisions so lots of spinning wheels. Very rigid in terms of benefits ande other policy decisions - one size fits all, no exceptions.

pros: Great benefits, great company, fortune 100 best company to work for, great 401 k benefit, my manager is very leniant, we are the world biggest lender and my manager is very easy going person to work for.
cons: The cons are basically, they make you worl very long hours, since I do mortageges my customers get very demanding at times. So I would say it's a very demanding job.

review_title: Bank of Opportunity - if you want it and want to work for it. No free rides
job_title: Senior Operations Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Enormous advancement opportunity if you work hard and navigate the corporate structure. Growth is definitely present and needs are growing everyday.
cons: Confusing corporate structure, too many changes that may or may not be communicated in a timely fashion. Need to always keep your eye out for opportunity. Negative view of company by general public

pros: Great benefits. Besides the medical, dental, & vision, they offer help with childcare for their employees.  There are ways for associates to get counseling and help when a crisis occurs. They  also help when associates are adopting a child. Before the incentives vanished they had payouts and reward point that you could get merchandise with.  Bank of America is very involved in the community and their employees log a lot of time working on charitable events. That is something I think most people should be proud of.
cons: On a branch and market level,  the people that were promoted to leadership roles are not the most knowledgeable, experienced, or hardworking, they are the "peppy cheerleaders" who can recite the company line (which changes with each market team change) and can  delegate and micro-manage.  They tell the Tellers that they are not Sellers but require them to get 3 referrals a day each.  It encourages manipulation and falsification.  They require more and more of the tellers and yet there is no incentive to work harder ,no rewards, other than "be glad you have a job" It's OK not to have rewards, but they make people feel threatened and stressed. When you are worrying about referrals more than the accuracy of your work then mistakes happen.

review_title: Bank of America, your employer of choice?
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: If you want to move up in the company, it's pretty easy.  You don't need an education to move up.  As long as you work the ranks and server your time, you can move up to a management position.  In many cases, upper management will hire managers that haven't had any prior banking experience.  This is a huge motivator for tellers and external candidates.
cons: In a sense, you get the feeling that upper management doesn't care about you (although they say they do).  They like to play favorites.  Salary can be frustrating as well.  I was always on the low end of the pay scale.  You put a lot of time and effort as a manager and you don't recognized for it.  All they care about is the end result...making your numbers.  I was with the company for 9 years and was a Banking Center Manager for 4 years and never got an AVP title.  There were a lot of new hire managers getting those titles.  When I asked my manager for the title, they either brushed me away or kept giving me action plans.  When you were successful with the action plan they would give you another one.  The most frustrating thing I experienced was when I was in the process of hiring an Assistant Manager.  Upper management decided to choose the AM for me rather than letting me make the choice.  I have hired a few AMs in the past, all of which I have been given the choice to hire on my own.  The one they hired had no operations experience and had only been with the company for a year.  They tell you that you are the general manager of your branch and you make all the decisions that are right for your branch but in the end they wind up doing it themselves without telling you.  It's great that you are able to become a branch manager without having any education to back yourself up (I had a bachelor degree in management) but what happens after that?  I felt as if there was no guidance for your career after that.

review_title: Finally left after 7 years to save what's left of my sanity
pros: The benefits are excellent - adoption, education reimbursement, medical, dental, vision, etc.  There are a lot of job opportunities because it is such a large company once you can get your foot in the door.  Tons of products are offered to fit just about any customer need.
cons:
There is no work life balance.  "Coaching" as they call it is a joke.  BCMs are expected to develop and coach their associates but we have no time to do so.  We get no coaching from management in return - unless you count 15 minute visits every couple of weeks where they walk in, look around, leave and then send you an email enumerating the ways in which you fail as 'coaching'.  

The staffing levels in the branches are a joke for the volume of customers we see.  They give you a staffing system that tells you how many tellers you need on any given day.  But the rub is if you follow that schedule to the letter?  You end up WAY over on your payroll hours.  They tell you to trust the schedule but don't give you the staff to MEET the schedule.

Training?  Yeah, good luck with that.  BCMs go to classes on role-playing how to be a manager and role-playing how to sell.  I already knew how to sell and how to be a manager - that's why I got the job.  There is no actual hands on training on systems, bank products, or operations - you know, the stuff you need to know to run your branch on a daily basis.  There is no investment in making sure that people in a position as critical as bank manager are properly prepared for the role.

I recently quit after nearly eight years with the company and have started a new branch manager job at a different large bank and it is a breath of fresh air.  I haven't been this relaxed and stress-free in about four years.  It feels great.  I can't speak for other lines of business within the company, but avoid the Consumer branches at all costs.  Especially at the management level.  The market I worked in has turned over more than 60% of its banking center managers in less than 2 years - and none of them got promoted within the company.  Every single one of them left for other banks, to work in other industries, or went out on stress leave and never came back.

I was successful as a BCM.  They tried to get me to stay when I gave notice.  I bonused every quarter (both semesters in 2010), but the payouts no longer made up for the ridiculous amounts of stress I was under.  My home life began to suffer as did my mental and physical well-being and no job is worth that.  My only regret about leaving is that I didn't do it sooner.

review_title: Very Stressful, make sure you open a lot of new accounts, but average experience!
pros: Opportunity for growth,  Pretty regular schedule, 9-6.  Nice benefits.
cons: You can't set your own schedule, your at the mercy of the bank.  Goals unreachable, too high, constantly changing.  They really don't care about their clients, always charging fees, be ready to deal with a lot of irate clients.

review_title: Saw no real job growth outside of the banking center.
pros: Benefits. Bank of America offered awesome benefits for both full-time and part-time workers. Really there was no much of a difference between the two positions. I got discounts to about every place you could name and the health benefits really provided security. Also, if your banking center met its performance goals everyone would receive a pay increase based off of the banking center manager's discretion. Within six months of working for the bank I experienced two pay increase as well as a monetary bonus for exceeding performance metrics.
cons: Although the bonuses were great, they cut that program right after I received my first bonus. And were told that we would still see raises if we met performance goals, but when I did get a pay increase it was pennies compared to the first couple of raises I experienced. This caused morale to go down and many of the tellers started to disregard our goals, because it just didn't seem worth it anymore. The worst part of the job (and this is highly dependent on the banking center) was management. It was all talk and no walk. Our managers preached to us about meeting goals and being customer-oriented, but did not display any of these traits in front of the staff. My Assistant Manager was the laziest of them all and also the meanest. She felt like she could get away with doing no work and put it on her team because she was in essence the boss. This environment didn't inspire me to excel and ultimately became the reason why I left the branch. As for Bank of America as a whole their goals were not focused which were the reason why it was hard to achieve any of the standards they release. One quarter it was customer service, then referrals, and after that credit card. We couldn't practice a process long enough before there was a new focus. All in all if you apply for this position don't expect to make it higher within the corporate organization. There are stories of people becoming market managers, but it is far and plenty and no one knows exactly what these positions are for. All in all I had a poor experience with the company.

review_title: Bank of America certainly promotes opportunities for individuals with aspirations in the banking industry.
pros: Bank of America encourages diversity amongst its employees and the ceiling is as high as you want. There are always opportunities to fulfill leadership roles.
cons: On the downside, having a diploma does not matter at certain levels within the company because they allow people to pursue careers with the bank without a diploma.

review_title: Worked for many large banks and my experience at Bank of America has been the least satisfying.
pros: Great paid time off benefits, minimum 2 weeks of vacation (depending on job band) with the option to buy an additonal week. 12 paid Maternity/Paternity Leave. Commuter benefits. Child care credits. Tuition Reimbursement.
cons: Very bureacratic. Very few opportunities for job growth within a division. Company boasts about employee development but performance plans are a joke- completed at the last minute and no accountability.

review_title: Good place to work while in College, but has it's downs.
pros: I think that management is good at communication with employees and helping as needed. I like how my schedule can be done to fit my college classes as well. The job itself is not hard, the pay is good for the position, and the benefits are great for part-time.
cons:
I do not want to to sound negative, but there are  some things that really bug me about this company. First off, I dislike how management tries to "brainwash" it's employees. An example would be the very controversial $5 debit card fee. When it was released that we will be charging, management said that it was a great deal for customers because it is a "service" that we are providing, and they encouraged us to tell customers that. After the amount of heat BOF got, and they took it away, management didn't think it was such a good idea anymore. Point here is that they try to make it seem as everything is gold, and it isn't.
Also, at least at my branch, they are putting a LOT of emphasis on referrals. I am a very fast teller, I consider myself to have great customer services skills, and I am efficient, being always on balance. Trying to do referrals can be stressful because many customers do not want any more services that what they currently have, so getting a credit card, or a checking account and saving everyday is difficult. Part time only need 2 referrals a day, but that won't do. We need at least 4 referrals, or else, supervisors and such won't be happy. But my branch is not easy, so maybe this does not happen everywhere.

pros: Good relationships with work peers, on site daycare, some departments approve of telecommuting, federal government will never let the bank fail
cons: Benefits cut every year 5 years running, frozen salaries, poor morale, focus on cost reductions while lip service is given to improving customer service, lack of vision, poor execution, strategy seems to be wait for Chase to do something and then try to copy it 6-12 months letter and while they're at it don't execute even when Chase has shown how to do it.

review_title: Terrrible Culture, Lack of Growth and Guidance
pros: International Brand Recognition between BOA and Merrill Lynch
cons: The culture is terrible. There is a lack of respect from Upper Management all the way down to the associates, who are treated as peopns. The benefits tho good are very expensive. We pay twice as much for benefits as our competition, and get paid at least a third less.

pros: Lots of nice people.  A lot of get togethers with other employees (potlucks, softball league, comedy clubs, etc).  Feedback to employees from management was a requirement and allowed the employee to set goals and expectations.  Recognition was always given where it was due.
cons: Projects teams are spread out throughout the country, so face-to-face time is non existent.  Project due dates and timelines are always super-tight, and almost always impossible to meet.

review_title: Poor sr mgmt ruining great company
job_title: Senior Vice President in Wilmington, DE
pros: Strong brand, diverse lines of business, great work life balance and benefits.  Good recognition culture. Opportunity is there for bac to outperform peers but poor decisions by sr mgmt.
cons: All lobs seems to be contracting vs peer are growing. Mgmt loses great talent while retaining people that dont know what drives business. Sense of loyalty that once existed is gone.

review_title: A great part-time position..with a few drawbacks
pros:
If you are looking for a good flexible part time position, then I recommend BofA.
-Healthcare
-Tuition Reimbursement
-No weekends (some Saturdays)
-Holiday paid time off (even for gov't holidays)
and more..
cons:
It's hard to disassociate personal experience compared to the overall position, but I'll try.
-First and foremost if you are going to be a teller you have to make sales.  This means you have to get at least 2 referrals a day. If you do not get your referrals you will be pulled aside but in a nice manner.

-It can become quite a competition as everyone is trying to get referrals.  You may make some enemies. You can't please everyone, but in a banking center with only 3 or 4 people working  on the teller line, it can be quite stifling.

-You may get a referral from a customer that you have worked really hard for.  But if personal bankers are busy, the customers will not wait.  Therefore, if they leave and never see the personal banker it is not considered a referral.

-Sick/Weather/Personal call outs are frowned upon.  This is nothing unusual because managers have a center to run and they need the tellers there.  However, there was one moment where an employee collapsed and had to go to the Hospital.  The banking manager asked the same employee later that day If they could come in after they were released. Quite ridiculous.

-Mid level managers can be lazy.
There have been plenty of times when I've seen head tellers pass their work off to regular tellers.  This is a problem as it creates favoritism.  The managers will treat the tellers who do their work with better care.

-Not enough recognition
While, they do recognize your efforts every once in a while with certificates of recognition, it would be nice to get some type of perk in return.  There is nothing offered to the employee who basically sells the customer into a new banking product.

review_title: Totally Employee centric, and security freak. Leaves nothing to chance when it comes to safety of customer's data.
pros: Ethical and values employees more than anything
cons: Very conservative for data protection, freaking and un-trusting employees, sometimes it is unnerving and seems unfair that offshore location, especially India, has to bear so many rules like no mobile phones allowed, no data device, music players allowed in office premises. But still this gives sense of pride that we work for absolutely ethical company

review_title: Great Company, still undergoing value transition
pros: Corporate culture promotes  inclusiveness, diversity and is focused on doing right thing for the client.Huge knowledge base, Huge skillset base. Bank of America is leader in technology implementations and has implemented almost all sorts of software applications. There is opportuinity to learn a lot.Bank allows work from home ( virtual- telecommute) which can be a boon if you are living in a city like LA etc. After buying several companies, Bank of America is in a position to do almost everything imaginable for the customer. They offer end to end services and a huge spectrum of financial products.If you are getting loan with Bank of America, you get a Clarity commitment. Other lenders not so much. BAC has very less hidden fees but is often victimized since it is one of the bigger banks. Bank offers a great learning opportuinity in that even if you end up leaving the company, your future employer will find you very valuable. Bank heavily outsources IT, which means you will work in a globally diverse team, which is a huge asset these days.
cons: No Merit increases, No Bonuses.Zero growth. Wage stagnation. No promotions since all technology positions are most likely induvidual contributor positions that keep on adding responsibilities in the wake of layoffs. For those of you that dont know, Bank of America is comprised of different cultures ( Legacy Bank of America ( Nations Bank) values are the advertised core values, but the acquired companies dont display the values at all times. Merrill culture ( shoot first, check later) ,CFC ( sugar coat as much as you can) are the most recent acquisitions  that are still trying to come to terms with legacy bank values.

review_title: The Bank offers endless career opportunities but the pay is less than market value
job_title: CMO (Customer Marketing Operations in Brea, CA
pros: The bank is very big on volunteering which I've done countless times and enjoyed and their benefits are outstanding. The bank gave me three months paid in full leave for for daughter. The bank will pay a small part of daycare and will give students five thousand a year for school which is pretty good. The bank offers a lot of training and is really good with updates and making sure everyone knows what we changes are coming. This place is great for those who are young and still live at home and don't pay rent. The opportunity to move around and change departments and move up is good.
cons: The bank pays poverty wages to their employee's and managers. The bank pays below market value and hires a lot of sub-standard people and you get the feeling that Bank of America hires anyone who they can low ball to do the job. They don't like college people and managers feel threaten by you because most management are high school graduates only.The bank will state to you that anyone can move up in management without and education and they will put you through their course designed for your exact job duties. Never mind the fact that people cannot speak or even dress professional. Their is a lot of dating that goes on between all ranks. My job is the biggest sales job in the whole call center and out of 800 other people across the nation who work in the same department as I do but in other states, the most anyone receives incentive wise is less than a thousand. Most people who work their don't bonus and most who do receive less than 400 for your efforts. The bank will tell you the pay is low  (usually 13-15 dollars per hour) and sell you on the bonus that no one makes. If they pay one guy a thousand dollars, which isn't a lot for a sales job, they can deceive you into believing its common place and that most people receive that; maybe thirty out of 800 might receive that and again that isn't a lot of money to begin with. Most people who work their are actively trying to leave. CMO has the highest turnover rate as far as people leaving, getting fired or quitting than any other department in the bank.

review_title: Despite what you read in the media, BOA is a great place to work!
pros: Awesome benefits!  Just to name a few that I, or my co-workers, have taken advantage of: matching 401k, health/dental/vision insurance, childcare reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, first time home buyer assistance, solar power program, hybrid car assistance etc.  There are too many benefits for me to list off but one that i take advantage of most often with my family would be free admission to many museums, aquariums and science centers.  The schedule also fits my personal life perfectly!  Its normal hours and a consistant schedule which I appreciate.  I am able to plan things in my life like doctor's appointments wihtout worrying about my schedule changing.  There is a great work-life balance even though it is a sales environment.
cons: There is constant negative media attention.  The bank tries to keep us informed with what is going on but it's hard when people believe everything they read and come in with an attitude.  Sometimes ignorance turns into hostility and it is tiring trying to remain professional and not take it personally.  Also, there is constant change.  Change in products, services, management, etc.  Just a lot of change in general so if you are not good at adapting to change this is not a company that i would reccommend for you.

review_title: Perfect place to work if there were simply more locations in our area.
job_title: Personal Banker in College Station, TX
pros: Wonderful support from our immediate managers. EXTREMELY family friendly and accepting. Compensation is comparable and benefits are second to none! If we could simply put in more locations in our area, I would give my company a 100 out of 100. With more locations, there would be NO better place to have a career.
cons: Few locations in our area. We are competing with Citi, Wells Fargo, and Chase who each have at least 4 to 8 locations in the area. Our local credit union has 5 locations now. We are the ONLY branch in the area. I've personally heard from more than 10 clients who have a net worth of over 1 million who have closed their accounts due to a lack of presence in South College Station, TX. They assured me that if we were to build even a small location in their area, they would bring ALL of their business to Bank of America. We have wonderful products and the best associates. We deserve to be represented by a larger footprint in the Bryan/College Station area.

pros: Bank of America is a great place to work.  Never worked for anywhere more positive with some many people happy with their jobs.  Recognition is part of almost all meetings and the culture is based on teamwork and encouragement.
cons: Seems the company is becoming much less attractive as benifits are reduced.  I think satisfaction and loyalty is going to decrease as insurance increases by 3% each year and pention is removed this year.  Also with the state of the economy, expenses and compensation has been reduced not keeping up with insurance costs increases and cost of living.

pros:
The only pro is the pay, of course- seeing as the economy is bad the pay is very decent if you're looking for a job that will keep you afloat.

You just need to know how to sell really well. 

You do not need a degree in business or banking.

Very volunteer oriented.
cons:
Micro-managing to it's finest! It's one thing to "coach" and direct someone but micro-managing is an entirely different thing.

The company will NOT let up or ease up on sales of products that are being shoved down customers throats who quite frankly will not get any use out of. They do not and refuse to change their marketing strategy. (in doing so they'll continue to fail- good luck with that!)

They promise that they will help and support your wanting to "move up" --- these claims are false. They understaff their branches to the point that somehow the managers can't seem to "let you go" meaning moving up would mean that they would lose a teller so they can't. So you suffer. You're overworked, doing tasks that someone in a higher position usually does still making lower pay. 

They claim to have an open policy, meaning you can even "coach" your own manager in wrong behavior or point out anything that she/he did wrong or goes against the usual rigid Bank of America Script (yes I said script) but in actuality, you'll get some lashes of attitude, unjust treatment and so on. And the longer your Manager has been with the company, the worse. 

UNDERSTAFFED- UNDERSTAFFED-UNDERSTAFFED- get read to juggle way too much. Two tellers for four windows? How does that even make any sense? Customers will always be irrate with the wait and you also get timed on how long customers wait. They never offer any help, or fix the problem they will just consistently blame it on the tellers. Two hands, two feet. Customers are trusting you the bank with their money. 

They offer Teller Supervisors to assist tellers on the line and supervise. Yet wait they fail to tell you is that this title is bogus. You are either a teller. Or you're a mid go-fer. Welcoming customers all day and dealing with issues that the manager should be dealing with. Do remember that the title is TELLER SUPERVISOR. So where does that leave supervision? Tellers are left alone waiting for overrides, customer help and anything else in between in limbo looking like fools in front of customers for minutes at a time (remember, you're getting timed !)

Training is absolutely horrible! How do you expect someone to come into the company and get trained by a computer from beginning to end with all computerized features? The customers are 3d images, your teller drawer, etc. Pathetic. Where is the hands on training? This is a multi bilion dollar bank with customers depending on the tellers firsthand to be able to navigate the system and products. They shut you in room all day for training at your selected branch, no help from anyone besides the prompter from the computer program. That is a huge RISK!!!!!! 
  
Get ready to live in this place. Late hours, early hours, 30 min break, when legally you're supposed to get one 30 and two 15 when working over 6 hours in massachusetts. And if you work below 6 hours....what break? 

You cannot be yourself. Of course every bank and credit union or financial institution has guidelines to follow but thats the key word "GUIDE" Expect constant negative feedback about not using specific wordage or lingos. Expect to become a robot. CUSTOMERS HATE THAT! CONSTANTLY COMPLAIN ABOUT IT! YET NO ONE CHANGES THIS! (you're losing your customers because they hate the bank's personality)

review_title: Bank of America - Voice of a Top Performing Manager
job_title: Banking Center Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Good Salary and Good Benefits (though the company match has gone down as it relates to healthcare coverage for the year 2013).
cons:
1. Upper management is out of touch with Associates in "front line" roles (specifically, the banking center channel). Due to falling revenue the Bank has had to layoff what they consider non-essential roles, while they seem to be smothering branch leaders and their staff, as well as market leaders ("market" aka district). The company is very routine/process focused, which is not a bad thing, however, it is oftentimes impossible to complete all of the tasks required and get the type of results that keep your job 'secure'. Lastly, and perhaps MOST importantly, I would like to point out: there is a Distinct disconnect and Lack of Opportunity for those who are Top performers in the Consumer and Small Business banking segment of this company. Those thatwork in Charlotte --the headquarters for BOA-- and who are not in the banking center channel, seem to have Many more opportunities than those that get literally "stuck" in theconsumer banking world.  You would think that the company would not only take the step of identifying top talent, but after doing so, would take necessary steps to leverage these talented individuals. The Consumer banking channel represents 70% + of the company's profits, yet there doesnt seem to be enough leveraging of individuals from this part of the business when it is time to employ process improvements/update/change/review tools and routines. There are several Departments (and Project teams) that focus on this leg of the business, though these departments Rarely include employees who have come up through the ranks of the consumer 'world' (even though many of them have received advanced degrees and are performing at the highest levels). I say all this to say that you must be careful what part of this Bank you get hired into, because you could be there (not learning or developing) for a very longtime regardless of well you do; it's almost like they want to selfishly keep you held hostage 'because' of how good you are (can't afford to lose you). Recently, there have been Many employees leaving BOA because of some of the above (not scientific, but I know several of them (and they, as was I, were Top Performers).
2. Training and Scheduling: the on the job training is not working. Associates are never fully prepared because there is little to No real quality time for training, especially since operations and the face to face time with customers is necessary to grow the business. You cannot get a gallon of juice from a piece of dried up fruit. Those who are not actively working in branches continue to ask for more: more processes to be completed, more operations to be done, more training, and of course more sales (understood because this is a for-profit corporation).  Quite frankly, I and my team were doing well, but I found working for this company to be simply too much of a strain on my personal life and overall health and well-being.
3. Recognition varies depending on the Leadership team. Salary was Great but Money just simply was not enough to make me stay. I got the same pay, with Better training, more support, and a better quality of life at another Financial Institution.
4. Branch Managers: you Own it All so be ready for the task at hand; if you are not truly a General Manager, it will be difficult for you to succeed at BOA.

pros:
Here's the thing BofA has been through tough times relatively compared even to other banks. I've been seeing perpetual layoffs since the day I started here. That being said I've survived here over four years and actually been promoted twice. I'm not a person who's been stuck or passed over for promotion, so maybe this will add some clarity to where I'm coming from and my full thoughts of the bank. I've gotten a chance to work on really interesting and difficult technology problems. I've received tons of mentorship and support.

+ Professional atmosphere - none of the "brogrammer" non-sense
+ Mentorship - even if the ship around us is burning down lots of talented folks willing to share their knowledge and advice
+ Dysfunction in technology divisions can be an opportunity to shine and distinguish one's self (also an easy way to get burned out and or become cynical)
+ Work from Home
cons:
The bad is really bad at BofA. Career growth can be a mine field. I've had several junior employees come to me about how they get no chance at exposure. Many in the tech divisions are so entirely exhausted from layoffs that they are either actively looking for other jobs or are just going through the motions.

+ Extreme cost cutting. Ever had to wrestle with an executive for $200 to fix production issue (ironically caused cost cutting in server maintenance)?
+ Executive musical chairs. Executive management changes every six months. No direction, confused direction, or misguided direction provided by management during their stints.
+ Work from home / flexible work is being eliminated
+ Career growth is a mine field and is accessible to only the most connected and politically savvy
+ Layoffs are perpetual feature and fear in the tech teams. In my four years, I've personally seen nine large scale layoffs--and that's not hyperbole.
+ Tech team quality has dropped significantly. Sophisticated developers and tech team members are leaving in droves or have already left. The quality of the tech talent left behind post layoffs and attrition is really poor. Lots of unmaintainable, undocumented, no test case, brimming with hacks code bases lying around.
+ Demoralizing environment for big thinking.

review_title: Worst treatment for a new mom!!
pros: As a Financial Solutions Advisor, they were ahead of banks like PNC and Fifth Third in terms of systems and technology.  The salary is by far the highest of any of the large banks and that is a major plus.  They give you a laptop.
cons:
They did not understand work-life balance.  They are extremely rigid in their 9-5 timeframe, not allowing for lunch out of the bank or any time out of the bank at all. As an advisor, that's normally unheard of as other banks allow you the flexibility to run your investment book as needed.
They also required you to make several "daily calls" on a recorded line with very specific scripting.  It was incredibly demeaning for any financial or sales person with years of experience.  But it's not easy to close business because their back office systems are lacking, but was getting better.
The worst thing about Bank of America was the Merrill Lynch side of the company.  Merrill Lynch-ers still think they are better than everyone and that thought bleeds through to the bank side.  
As a dual-employee of both Bank of America and Merrill Lynch, I'd stay far away from Merrill Lynch.  That side of the company should have gone under when it was going under in 2008.  Their egos are unbelievable!!!  Even for someone like myself who's been in the industry long enough to see the major egos in this industry, Merrill Lynch-ers are by far the worst.  STAY AWAY!!!
They do not want to tell you details about roles on their side of the company because they're "just too complicated" when it's really they want to remain elitist.
They are also extremely sexist and disgraceful to women and new moms.  NO WAY a place for women with children.  They treated new moms TERRIBLY!!!!  Every one of their competitors is so much better with that aspect.
For people who want to be real advisors, skip Merrill Lynch/Bank of America and go to a real firm.

review_title: FCOM, Personal Banker/RM, Teller/CSR, RB Beware!!
pros: Great Hours, Great benefits, good technology. BOA has great benefits and amazing hours, while I worked there I had a great work life balance. Some centers open Saturday from 9-1pm, most offices close at 4pm and employees are usually out of the office by 5pm. Bank accounts are free for employees and other bank products are given at a discount. Goals are achievable and incentives are lucrative if you are a good seller.

If you are not referred by a relative, friend or connection that can help you become a member of a "clique" or an "in-crowd" you won't stand a chance. If you are looking to build a career and work your way up the ladder within a reasonable amount of time, BOA is not the place for you. Don't expect to be promoted if you don't have the right connections, regardless of your experience or having an MBA. During the time I was employed there no one got promoted unless they were "well connected" I saw many people get passed over for less experienced associates with the right connections. 
     The minute someone who is a member or a group or "clique" decides they don't like you or thinks you may be competition, forget it you are done for. They call all their friends (who many are Managers) and harass you in order to secure your immediate departure.  Senior leadership won't help, it does not matter if you are a good employee, they will not put a stop to the nonsense. Leaders see the bullying happening right under their nose and turn a blind eye, I believe that management in many cases encourages this behavior. 
     I was left alone most of the time because I was quiet, but a girl I worked with for a few  months was constantly harassed by some of our co-workers.  The bullying was so bad that I would always catch her tearing up. I think she was targeted because she was an outsider who had  experience and wanted to get ahead, our manager (clique member) did not like her. It felt horrible to see the abuse towards her and see how she was wasting away, I could see that our manager would condone the behaviour towards her and in my opinion encouraged it. I wanted to help her, but was too afraid of my own back and job to do anything about it. I chose to find another job and left instead.

cons:
*Hours- work 6 days a week for centers open on Saturdays, for those that are solo in a center, expect to work open to close, with no day/time off during the week unless it's a holiday.

*SUPER MICRO management, from everything you do- how you greet customers, how you get them to your desk, what and how you say it, how you use the programs on your computer to service them, how many customers you follow up with daily, even the moment you sign in and out of your computer-- EVERYTHING is monitored and reported to your managers, and then, on top of that, you then have to calculate all of this information into your own reports that they already have access to, and if you don't do the above, you end up on lists that all of the sellers and managers in the market sees.

*Even if you are EXCEEDING sales goals and expectations for your monthly/quarterly numbers, you are made to feel as though it still isn't good enough from your Market manager. They will continue to try to improve you, and monitor you to see what you are doing that is 'holding back' your sales potential. Nothing wrong with doing better of course, but when you feel like you might get fired even when you are doing extremely well on your sales is absurd! There is little acknowledgement for accomplishments because the small applause given for hitting numbers is overshadowed by the many lists you are on for not making enough calls, or not using CMC enough, etc. etc.

*If you are a single seller you will have short lunches and no breaks and are expected to work everyday except Sunday, every week. Also if you are short on staff, you will be expected to do operational tasks even though this is NOT your job and NOT what you are getting paid for, and takes away from your selling time.

*Market Managers not on same page as Financial Center Managers, which makes it a headache and frustrating for the Relationship Managers. Examples include use of Discover Tool (how and when to fill it out with all of your customers), Customer Experience tactics, lobby leadership, etc.

*Mandatory monthly sellers meetings which can last until 7PM, or market calls which require you to be at the bank more than an hour before opening (this is at least paid for).

pros: Great place to work, very compliant, I enjoy the experience, lots of opportunities to progress
cons: Stay Compliant, follow procedures and don't get involved in gossiping, try to progress yourself by learning your job in every way or clients will avoid you

job_title: Relationship Manager in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The benefits are not bad considering the fact that we are given 3 weeks of paid vacation, 10 sick days that we can use, tuition reimbursement, child care reimbursement, 401K with up to 5% matching, and 4 months of paid maternity leave.
cons: Where do I begin? I feel as if though the benefits are put in place more or less as a deterrent to entice you not to quit as opposed to really allow you to enjoy and use them. As a so called, "Relationship Manager", you face an insurmountable amount of pressure that resonates with an incredible push to sell products and to meet goals. Never have I worked in such a position in which goals were being shoved down the associate's throats as I have witnessed here. This job is ideal for individuals that may not have a proper university education i.e. 4-year degree or maybe for those that wish to use it as a lynch pad to get into home loans or Merrill Lynch. There is constant micromanaging in the form of having to send and reply to emails that nearly tend to be negative, having to get on phone calls all the time, and literally having to role play a set list of questions and responses in order to help facilitate selling products. This role is not for the faint of heart. It will literally drain you of your mental capacity and energy. The compensation is not very good at all. In reality, it's laughable at best. You are promised a "salary" but it is really just hourly pay multiplied by a maximum of 40 hours and then multiplied once more by 52. You do have the ability to receive a bonus at the end of every quarter but keep in mind, it is incredibly difficult to bonus especially when your goals seem to increase month after month without much explanation. Yeah they talk about wanting you to succeed and to do well in your role but honestly, this company has so many internal problems that it eventually demoralizes you from wanting to give it your best. It is dysfunctional with a lack of true leadership. Don't get me wrong, there is an influx of bosses but no true demonstration of leadership. Perhaps that would explain the revolving door as far as having an incredible amount of people that quit the relationship manager role within their first year as turnover seems to be high with this position. Even long time clients that have spent years at their local financial center will take notice of this as they will tell you that new people are always working at the bank when they come in. My advice to you, if you are thinking about working here, is to think about your decision. Take it with a grain of salt. It may seem impressive to put down Bank of America as past experience on your resumé but get ready to be pushed to the brink of mental exhaustion and losing your sanity in order to meet these high sales goals that are put forth upon you.

pros: Loved the people I worked with. Loved the customers. Good benefits.
cons: Very focused on selling products. The focus was not on doing what was best for the customer. It was selling products and that was what would be best for the customers and that would be how you would keep your job.

job_title: Relationship Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: High turnover rates equals more opportunity. Good benefits package with helpful educational topics for maximizing financial growth. In general, good mission statement. Solid career tracks but long term commitment expectation. Long term, 5 to 10 years, it should be a great place to work. When you get the right manager, working here can be fun.
cons:
Terrible incentive plan. Quarterly incentive cut by extraneous factors. 
Company direction unclear, lots of flip flopping by management, no clear communication with employees and
Inability to nurture career growth. Horrible hr staff. Once you leave you really feel how unimportant you were. 
Lacks proper technology updates, branches seriously lacking in standard equipment. Lack of feeling rewarded for working hard. Lack of trust building with employees. Too many chiefs too little Indians. Company currently forcing staff into direct conflict with clientele base. Company wants a faster culture-shift from doing transactions in branch without recognizing that in many cases clients are so fed up, or still legitimately lack alternatives, that their treatment of staff is regularly abusive, even if approached in the most textbook way the company requires.

pros: The processes, procedures, risks, policies, and data metrics are the key to the company. The culture of the workplace is very diversified and everyone is open and willing to assist and help in many ways. The management is very supportive and they listen to everyone's concerns and questions which may bring them up in Town Hall meetings. There are many equal opportunities within the company to move around or up.
cons: Sometimes it may be strict on policies and risks due to the financial sector but its understandable. Micromanagement can be seen time to time.

review_title: Enjoyed My Time at Bank of America - May Even Go Back
pros:
Great Teammates.
Clear message as to why you are there: to make customers financial lives better through the power of every connection.
Good benefits - not just health care and 401k but employees are also give the highest tier status for accounts - Preferred Rewards Platinum without having to keep large balances in their accounts
Very good corporate citizen - many opportunities to do volunteer work 
$15 per hour minimum wage corporate-wide
Full-time benefits for part-time workers
cons:
Biggest downside is that not everyone drinks the Kool-Aid around making financial lives better ... as with every organization you have people that are just there to pick up the twice monthly paycheck ... what's the expression: "Everyone who leaves quits but not everyone who quits leaves."

Still have some "old school" rules that really don't make sense - you don't need to wear a suit and tie to look (and be) professional.  Bank continues to "overdress" for its clients ... I believe that creates barriers to building relationships ... another "old school" rule I don't like is the need to get your manager's permission to post for another role in the Bank - guess what, you don't have to get permission to post for a job OUTSIDE the Bank ... if you are doing your job as a manager you will know what your teammates want to do and you will be invested in their success ...

pros: A lot of mobility within BofA, decent pay for a low level retail banking job and  competitive benefits. Great way to start and work your way up over the years.
cons: This enviroment forces you to sell under pressure, making you less of an finanical advisor and more of a used car salesman

pros: The department often does fun things for associates. You won't go hungry at work. They celebrate every national food day you never knew existed. Friendly associates.
cons: No schedule flexibility. Some of the management team is shady. They are clearly doing a lot of trial and error. Some days calls are back to back for the majority of your shift. Customers are truly unnecessarily incoveinienced and we are left to deal when the issues could be more of a one call resolution.

job_title: Foreclosure Specialist II in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Being able to assist my teammates and others who were not on my team with their issues for loans that were in foreclosure was something I took pride in.  The people were great, managers were wonderful, it was just a really great place to work.
cons: When loans were not reviewed properly and mistakes were made, which caused the sale to be postponed or the file had to be closed and we had to start all over.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: helping clients understand their banking needs. providing i formation. assisting clients with their accounts. being in a positive envirnment. learning products and information. showing empathy and conern about their issues. problem solving.
cons: working nights. no room for growing within the company. not knowing how to work as a team. manager has no time for feed back or coaching to help with my overall preformance

pros: There are a great deal of opportunities if you work outside of the banking centers. Most of the people I worked with had been with the company for 5 to 40  years so there is a chance for longevity. The benefits are excellent and can be extended to family and partners.
cons: If you don't know the right people it can be hard to move into a new role. Networking is critical. There are also frequent org changes so its possible to be moved into new roles every or under a new executive every year.

pros: Great Benefits and great coworkers.
cons:
When I first started with the bank almost 4 years ago, the environment was that of excitement for the future. Innovation was on the way, great new tools were coming available to help us better serve the clients. 

My first job was in one of our financial centers. The banks model was to expect us to achieve ridiculous sales goals, while simultaneously driving the customer away from the in person service to digital and phones, by slashing the amount of staff on hand in a Financial Center. Couple that with a micromanagement philosophy, that frankly, has redefined that word. 

From there I moved to the call centers. At first it was a nice change. Fast paced, but if you wanted to take a minute or two to converse with you cube mate, no one cared. If was a fun atmosphere. It did not take long for the toxicity to spread, however. Currently, the expectation is to log in at the start of your shift and do not log off your phone unless it is one of your 15-minute breaks or your thirty-minute lunch. Every second of your time is tracked. Every single second of your day must be accounted for.  Couple that with the banks other philosophy of " responsible growth". That is code for doing more with less...far less across the board. The staffing levels in my particular department were so low that the customer hold times were more than 90 minutes, with an abandon rate of over 50%. Yet they expected us to, in addition to sales, have near perfect customer satisfaction scores.

Management...here his a key point. Very few of the remaining managers in preferred sales/Advanced Client Solutions have EVER done your job. The one that have all left, and their replacements are nothing more than well-trained company "yes men". They do not care about you the employee. They only care about advancing their own careers.  They are perfectly content pushing policies and procedures that make zero sense, because at the end of the day...they don't have to do your job.

To be fair, there are great departments in the bank, that are more in line with what they advertise on their career page. But I would not, under any circumstances recommend anyone work as a front-line customer service/sales rep.

Their yearly "employee satisfaction survey" is a joke. They actually have each team in my department take the survey together, in a separate room and have a manager in there coaching us on all of the great things that came out of the survey in previous years, etc etc. They even give us candy. There are always big changes that some after the survey is over....just not good ones. We have a year to quit or forget.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Chula Vista, CA
pros: Good benefits, has opportunity with everything else
cons: Management has understaffed all financial centers. This leads to daily abusive comments by customers and a lack of work life balance.  I am expected to work 6 days a week, open to close, to make up for the lack of team members. Due to running skeleton crews, management cannot call out sick, it isn’t allowed, you are not allotted two weeks vacation in a row unless you hit your sales goals, and you are expected to be available by phone 24/7 and there is no recognition to be had. Everything comes from the perspective of “what you didn’t do correctly”

job_title: Vice President Operations in Addison, TX
pros: Generally Good Management, although from my perspective Senior Management is too hands on and tends to quickly get into the weeds.  Other than this I think the management structure is very sound and supportive.  Policies and Procedures are consistent, salary and benefits are very good.  Staff overall is knowledgeable, productive and good to work with.
cons: Like most Banks, if you are a salaried employee, particularly an officer you are going to struggle with the work/ personal life balance. For me, it was just the nature of the environment.  Things have deadlines

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Overall, the jobs pay well at Bank of America, and there is the added benefit of all those wonderful bank holidays.
cons: The culture is lacking. All in all, people are there to get ahead, and they'll step on anyone to do it. I've never worked anywhere else where people were more willing to take credit for my work.

review_title: global banking an markets technology  management
job_title: Vice President Operations in New York, NY
pros:
generous vacation if you can find the time to take it. 

The real powerful bureaucracy and enterprise policies are being run by simpletons out of Charlotte - especially out of Chief Data Office and Consumer Banking.  The real smart people of Global Banking and Capital Markets in New York are being held in a pen  and not allowed to participate or lead enterprise level activities.  Thankfully, we have a good advocate in Tom Montag who is the firm COO and Global Banking and Markets Champion, so whenever the simpletons in Charlotte come up with something mindbogglingly ridiculous, he just vetoes it and makes up his own rules.

pros: Great place to work! Have met some great people that I will call friends for the rest of my life! The compensation can be very good. There is great opportunity to grow and move up. They have a very good mentor program. very understanding when time off is needed to take care of family.
cons: hours can be very long. Need to watch who you say t hings to. 1/2 lunch is to short to go anywhere. rewards and recognition has been taken away. It was a very wonderful program.

review_title: Huge comapany many opportunities, but God forbid if you ever make a mistake.
job_title: Teller Operations Specialist in Kirkland, WA
pros:
Bank of America is a huge company.  In the market that I worked there were about 50 banking centers in les than 20 square miles and they are sqread throughout most of the company.  This is great for employees who move because it is easier to be get a position at another BofA if you are currently working for one.  Two teller that worked for me both transfered from BofA's in CA and even though WA is on an entirely different computer system their understanding of basic bank rules and culture allowed them to be ready to work in days rather than weeks or months for a brand new employee.

The Benefit package at BofA was amazing.  Tuition reimbursent of $5,000 a year is larger than most companies I've been around, matching 401k plus pention, medical, dental, vision, employee discounts at most major companies in the country because they bank with BofA.

Depending on your banking center there can also be an amazing sense of family among the employees especially the tellers, TOS, and AM.  It take a little more work for the sellers be apart of the family due to placement in the banking center and different goals in thier roles.
cons: They don't look at the whole when it comes to their employees.  If it's time for a review they look at sales and accuracy but if it's time for correction they completely disregard past successes.  While I was their four employees were fired including myself due to performance losses, or being taken in by fraudulent checks.  One employee took a very sizable loss in the thousands of dollars but looking at his sales for that quarter he brought in tens of millions of dollars in new mortgages not to mention he was the leading seller of checking accounts for the next two years I had customers come in on at least a weakly basis to close their accounts because he was no longer working there.  In the long they lost millions of dollars when they could have instead gone through a probation period and thouroghly trained the employee in loss control.  I feel I was a similar situation though I was not a seller I did not bring in individual sales numbers as the TOS and longest working employee at the banking center I was very well known among the customer base.  After leaving I have been told by various former customers and current employees that my asbsense has caused numerous people to leave the bank.  In these times of economic hardships customers expect their bank to feel secure and when the people they see and trust get fired they no longer trust the bank.

pros: There is a great work/life balanceat Bank of America.  The Bank is so large that there are many opportunities to move into different areas if you are persistent.
cons: Office politics are very clear.  There are many roles in commercial banking that are rather dead-end.  Advancement in commercial lending is not structured like investment banking...it could take years to move into a position you want.

review_title: Good benefits, lots of opportunity, but not much control and individuality
pros: You can find just about anything your interested within the Bank to move your career towards as it is a huge company requiring just about every skillset.  Working remotely and flexible work environments have become very popular with the Bank.

pros: The benefits are generally good.  My wife and I adopted recently and had the company reimburse us 8K per child, and an additional 90 days of paid maternity leave.

The health plans offered or either quite pricey and do not cover nearly as much as they used to, or the plans are inexpensive, but with a huge premium if we actually go to the hospital.  It takes a significant amount of money out of our paycheck.

review_title: Although Bank of America is a great company to work for, be aware of this title. It is somewhat misleading.

cons: Fraud Analyst is a misleading title. Although this position entails detecting fraud, it more so involves handling and resolving customer complaints and servicing. It should be titled Fraud/Customer Complaint Operator to eliminate any confusion of future applicants.

pros: Bank of America was my first real big corporate kind of job. So the whole hiring process was fairly amazing to me. It is a great place to start your career and there are lots of opportunities for growth within the branch. Getting to work at corporate is difficult though.
cons: Lots of the customers can be difficult and hard to explain procedures to. The frequent audits are also tiring to constantly prepare for.

review_title: Smart people, terribly political promotion process after VP, beaurocratic, too large

Smart people

review_title: It has been a very frustrating experience at times.
job_title: Small Business Relationship Specialist in Tampa, FL

review_title: They will dangle a carrot, but no follow through.
pros: Flexible work agreements.  There are some very good leaders within your work groups.  Bonuses are alright, except they are given in a filter down method.
cons: Managers spend too much time away from the employees job.  Managers spend too much time learning the employees job, then manager is changed.

review_title: "It's who you know, not what you know" type of environment....
pros: BENEFITS! Which include a good health/401k/pension plan and a big plus, tuition reimbursement.
cons:
There are so many! Mostly, it's hard to move up. It is truly a "who you know, not what you know" type of environment. When there are postings for a position that is a step up in the department, management already know who they want but they open the position for others to apply because they have to....this is a waste of time. You tend to see people promoted that do not have the skills or knowledge for the role. Sadly, it happens way too often. Don't get me wrong, on occasion, you'll see someone move up that is truly skilled but it's rare and those people tend to jump through many hoops to get there.

I work in a call center environment. I thiink that goals are not reasonably set. The company says they are customer-centric and that their satisfaction is very important. However, AHT goal is set so low that I feel that it is a rediculous goal to truly achieve customer satisfation. Reps tend to rush their calls to reach goal but at the cost of quality. Sales goals are also a huge negative. If a customer is expressing inability to pay, how are reps still force to try to sell? In todays environment, cross-selling is expremely hard especially since people don't tend to call unless they have an issue or are extremely upset. Ask yourself, when was the last time you called about your deposit accounts, credit accounts or mortgage?

Management....well that's a coin toss. I've had great and terrible managers. Selection really needs to be better....but that is what happens when you promote people for the wrong reasons.

review_title: Hard to work for a large corporation - you are just a number.

review_title: If you excel at your job then there is room for promotion. If you are average, then it is easy to get stuck in a rut.
job_title: Customer Relationship Manager in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Good benefits.  In addition to a 401k with company match Bank of America, also has a decent health package, and also matches a portion of salary towards the employee's "pension."
cons: Because the bank is such a big holder of Fanniemae mortgages, it is subject to the constant changes within FannieMae's policies.

review_title: Fast fast paced. Security a priority. Promotion in security based on presentation not on business value.
pros:
Pay & Benefits is reasonable for environment. Small increases, larger payout. 4 wks + 10 holidays=30 pd days off.
 Many opportunities in technology, compliance, audit. Work on new & leading edge technology and related policies, processes in technology and business divisions.
Every day is new, reactive.  Proactive planning and work account for the 20 after work hours per week. A must to maintain.
HR is slowly weeding out managers who cannot manage. With 300,000 employees it is slow moving.
cons:
BAC has a long term trend of hiring just the average or just under average (verified from a high performer who worked for BAC 4 times, each from an acquisition, over past 25 yrs). 
High performers who can keep up with the politics and pace start leaving 3 -5 yrs. The standard is to roll 10% employees per year (30,000 +). Many many top performers get caught in wrong place wrong time during cuts.
BAC is experiencing a brain-drain of cultural knowledge and systems knowledge.
Many technical managers are light on people management skills. Technical skills are very strong single silo with preconceived 'how-it-works' . Very bad for  architecture concepts.

I was laid off for political reasons. My mgr & I were assigned a very large project my indirect (siloed technical background) manager directed as very low priority - this technology was not going to be used in the bank. My indirect mgr, to impress his manager, failed all my work in very disparaging terms in front of his manager and the extended team. His manager disagreed, high-lighted my work, explained why my work was important to the bank and that I was one of the few who could lead the effort. The 'deer-in-the-headlights' look of my indirect manager being 'corrected' in front of the extended team ensured I was on the way out.

My ratings are based on two very poor managers in last five years since acquisition.
So I  say I am weak in politics. 
My peers say both these managers did not know how to manage and use smart people.
It is what it is. Wrong place, wrong time.

review_title: Corporate Culture trying to find its Identity
job_title: Market Information Manager II in Charlotte, NC
pros: Good vacation time, decent pay, ability to work from home.
cons: Market Research is so understaffed, that blocking employees from moving to other divisions is common (so, not a Bank of Opportunity). Frozen hiring means teams have withered away, so there are many seasoned people who have no "management" experience to put on resume. Teams are top-heavy, and promotions are rare.

job_title: Marketing Operations TSA II in Beachwood, OH
pros:
good pay for the work you do - average pay in the department starts at 13+/hr

amazing flexibility in their part time department - you can come can go as you please and take as many breaks as you like so long as you make up the hours you owe.

benefits are amazing. you can have executive level benefits at thrift store prices because its all based on how much you make. 

The company is always giving you something. be it food, drinks or just a fun night out at a local bar for a company event.
cons:
Customers that think they don't have to pay bills - customers will complain non stop about "fees" because of late payments or some variation of it.

Customers that think they're the best customers despite NEGATIVE balances - these customers are something else demanding up and down that they want free this and free that despite the overflowing negative balance in their checking accounts

Customers that think a phone call causes them grievous and mental anguish. - this department makes outbound customer service calls. all we want to do is say thank you and illustrate the benefits of your new product. nothing more nothing less. yet some customers feel put upon when "THE BANK" calls. if you don't like customer service drop your cards go join a credit union and stay out of the mall and all retail stores. its absolutely ridiculous. We don't sell, we don't push "insurance" on you. Bank of America has dedicated INBOUND sales marketing teams. You will never receive an outbound sales call. honestly who sells stuff over the phone anymore this isn't 1986 people. 

Certain Management - the entire management team are your peers who have done the job longer than you. most managers have been on the phone for 6+ years. but due to the fact a lot of them take advantage of the fact they aren't held to any strict medium. so they are never at their desk and constantly take breaks usually 5 or 6 in a day. anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour. 

Phone Job - All the above really comes down to the simple fact that you have a phone job. if you can't fathom sitting at a desk making 70+ calls during a 4 hour shift and 90+ during a 6 hour shift. don't apply.

review_title: overall positive experience but slowly started to decline
pros: The bank offers good hours, it also offers benefits for any employee who is hired on as a 20 hour employee (you still have to contribute, but still affordable). paid holidays.
cons: In recent years Bank of America has been massively cutting back the labor force which makes it very difficult to give customers the attention they deserve. Granted this is due more to government regulations then anything else it still makes it difficult to do your job properly.

review_title: Heavily sales and customer service oriented but not enough care for employees
job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Great insurance benefit package through Aetna, 401k, 3 weeks vacation for full-time employees with option to purchase time off. The company also offers great benefits such as tuition reimbursement and  $3000(I think?) reimbursement for the purchase of a hybrid car. There are also a number of associate inclusion groups, giving employees many chances to network and be involved. The company also encourages volunteer work and will pay for 2 hours.
cons: This company gets a bad reputation in the media so it's difficult to combat some of the misleading information that customers are hearing. The company itself is also too big so it's difficult to adequately handle customer issues. This results in a negative customer experience and a negative employee experience, as each banking center is expected to achieve a high professional treatment score based on customer surveys. Also, the sales and referral goals for tellers and personal bankers are too high and unrealistic and the managers micromanage their staff to achieve these numbers, creating a very stressful environment to work in. Another negative part is that tellers are expected to achieve these high numbers but are the only staff in the banking center not compensated by an incentive plan. This year, it has also become the "norm" for managers to schedule their staff to work six days a week.

review_title: great benefits, lots of opportunity thru out the company due to its size and promotion of growth,

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II Mandarin in Pasadena, CA
pros: The pay rates are better than working at restaurants. You also have a bunch of paid sick days and vacations from day 1. Insurance benefits offers a quite good coverage with a moderate price. You can also save a few dollars by using the discount program.
