job_title: Senior Vice President in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Complex organization offering all aspects of banking and almost everywhere. 
Easy and hard to get exposure to other areas and perhaps jobs in those areas.  Easy in that you get introductions to these areas and work on your connections.  Hard in that you may have to be geographically flexible and lots of other people are doing the same. The work is challenging and fulfilling.   I had a great career there.
cons: So large and complex, can be hard to connect with the right people.

review_title: My Branch Manager Verbally Harassed me!
pros: They offer great benefits. I was lucky enough to work with an awesome team and build friendships. I loved the 9-5 schedule.
cons: They expect too much for very little pay. My manager was uneducated and acted as if some of the employee benefits were coming out of her paycheck. She refused to sign my tuition reimbursement forms because I didn't meet the 2 a day referrals- which didn't make sense because I was a part-time teller and was required to have referrals for the days I was scheduled off! So if I was scheduled for 3 days I needed 10 referrals instead of 6. It was impossible to catch up. The assistant manager understood that the goal was impossible and she did sign the forms. My uneducated manager did everything she could to make my life miserable. She was extremely unprofessional she once told another co-worker that maybe if she wore a little makeup her bf wouldn't have broken up with her. She would speak badly in front of customers in front of other customers. She threatened to fire me because of my referrals at least once a month. I ended up getting really sick due to stress and I had to quit. I NEVER complained to HR about her bullying and harassment when I should have. I honestly think that I could have sued BOA for what she did to me. I was saddened at the fact that she verbally harassed me in front of everyone and no one ever said anything, but then again they were all afraid of her. Oh, and she would rather bring in new hires than promote within. The only time she promoted a teller to a PB position was a young guy who she had a crush on. There was a Senior Teller there that had been there 15 years and she still had not been promoted! That's insane, I would have quit ages ago if I were her! Once a year we were forced to fill out an "ANONYMOUS" survey where we were allowed to rate our managers and state any problems....she pulled me in her office and said "I know it was you that gave me a bad rating".

review_title: Too big to function... but ok place to work (depending on your manager)
pros:
Decent pay

Mobility options encouraged throughout the company

Some awesome managers
cons:
Some terrible, horrific managers - watch out for those

Not always paid for performance (even though they say it is)

Terrible IT systems that need to be updated (still working through past mergers and not enough investment)

Hard to be promoted past a certain level (waiting for seniors to move on or die...)

Lots of redundancies - job security is poor.  I've seen some awesome senior level people who have been there for decades let go.

review_title: Horrible company to work for. No one gives a Sh#* including the VP's. Dead end job. No room for growth. Very low ceiling
job_title: Business Control Analyst in Simi Valley, CA
pros: They were the only one's hiring but that's come to a close since they're selling off all their loans. other than that there no pro's. Everyone gets three weeks of paid vacation and most departments  allow you to buy one extra week of vacations if you've been with the company for more than a year but the way everything seems to be going it does;t loom like people in the mortgage side of BAC will last that long.
cons: Pay, room for advancement, pay, pay pay. Managers, employees don't know what they're doing. No accountability.

review_title: Poor, unprofessional leaders who are unqualified but highly touted, nonetheless....
pros:
Culture is shifting and improving internally and new focus is on various Lines of Business working together to accomplish the greater goal. 

Work, life balance can be achieved in certain roles outside of the Banking Centers.

Overall benefits package is generous. This is a nice perk in today's environment.

The brand on the street and in communities is slowly improving. The Bank has done a great job of riding out the storm and changing the perception on Main Street.
cons:
Poorly qualified Senior level executives are in roles they are unqualified for. Somehow, they build up enough tenure and are placed in positions to lead based on that alone. Meanwhile, they are impacting the lives of some very talented, up-and-coming professionals and stunting their growth. It is surprising that these unqualified, unprofessional 'executives' manage to remain in their roles and fly under the radar for so long.

Honesty is shunned, unless you are praising the Bank. When questions are asked to improve operations, you are better off remaining quiet or you will be blacklisted for good. Drink the Kool Aid and put your head down. That is the best means for survival in a shark tank such as this. 

No room to grow if you are at a certain level or Band 4 or 5. If you find an opportunity outside of  the Bank, you will undoubtedly make more money. 

Banking Center associates are treated poorly. They are underpaid, over- worked and have very little opportunity to qualify for bonuses based in unrealistic incentive goals. Moral, amongst this group, is low.

job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: Solid brand with detailed training; however, all computerized so hard to remember everything when you first start off. Great benefits and tuition reimbursement. New incentive plan rolled out for all associates, including the tellers. Also, if you are a top performer in your market every quarter, sometimes they do special recognition meetings. I work in a smaller branch and that has helped form tight relationships and a great work dynamic.
cons: Where do I begin? HEAVY emphasis on sales, even though the incentive for it is quite low (for teller/SSS). Goals are unrealistic and too high if you work in a busier banking center--thus making your work environment very stressful due to high expectations. Raises every year, but are so low that it barely makes any sort of difference in your pay. Usually the hardest working employees are the least paid. I have been a top performer in my market every quarter, and have gotten some recognition for it, but would be nice to actually feel you are making a difference in the company versus just being a number. There is not a lot of room for growth, and advancement is not based on meritocracy. Management tends to micromanage like crazy, especially the market and area executives. If you went to college and have a degree thinking it will help you move up quickly, forget it. Your degree is basically useless because it will not get you a promotion or a raise. Frequent changes--which is expected. However, you get used to one thing and they change it.

review_title: Review for Equity Research subsidiary of Bank of America
job_title: Equity Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: I made a career switch into the capital markets subsidiary from management consulting.  The equity research division for which I worked was a small team, and the peer on-boarding was fantastic.  Total compensation and benefits package was also good for a career switcher.
cons: Management was tough at times and due to the nature of the long work schedule, communications were not always clear.  Overall, it was a great professional learning experience and provided a representative environment for a job in the capital markets.

review_title: Lack of Training and Miserable Work Experience
job_title: DIL Specialist in Simi Valley, CA
pros: Good Pay, Good Benefits and a decent amount of PTO
cons: Lack of training, no structure to work. Im a DIL specialist but never received training for Deed in Lieu and have had my workload stripped and replaced with different files 4 times in the last 2 months. Lots of demands but no instruction on how to meet the goals they want you to achieve. No room for growth or opportunity to climb the corporate ladder

review_title: Strong company with solid pay and benefits, do your job and they will leave you alone
pros: Great benefits- low cost per pay period and great options, flexibility with schedule, generous attendance policy, fun monthly department meetings, many treats and activities for holidays and special events throughout the year, promotions available, decent cafeteria, free banking
cons: Not much room for growth in call center- team lead, manager, bounce to a different department-that's it, call centers can be "catty", job can be boring

pros: I enjoyed the flexibility of the job. I was able to work at Bank of America and be a full time student thanks the the management recognizing the importance of an education.
cons: Pay was decent but the monthly goals were unrealistic.  We had to open a specific number of accounts each month but reaching this goal only happens by chance. If a person comes in looking to open an account and I direct them to the personal banker that counts!!!! I didn't like that reaching the goals were out of my control and based solely on chance.

review_title: Very good and very bad all at the same time!
pros: Great training programs, benefits, time off (hello, it's a bank!) , leadership was always close by and supportive. Good work-life balance, benefits for part-time employees, guaranteed hours, focused on building relationships with customers and getting to know them and their situations before suggesting products. They taught us to help customers with their finances and to avoid fees which made me feel good about what I was doing.
cons: The whole mortgage nightmare was a horror!! Even as an employee, they took over 9 months to put my refinance through, dumped me twice, lied on my docs, then told me I had to start over at a higher rate! They got so big so fast they could not keep up with their systems. It took 13 years for WA and ID to be on the same system as the rest of the US making it challenging to explain to customers. We often did not have the tools or resources to do our jobs well.  After the crash there was restructure after restructure so leadership was lost and confusing.

job_title: Customer Relationship Manager II in Charlotte, NC
pros: The compensation is good and the benefits are better. At this company you do not pay for short term disability or long term disability. If you are hurt the benefits will make sure that you return with your job in tack.
cons: It is a crab in the barrel type of enviroment. In this company it is not about what you know. It is all about who you know. This has lead to poor leadership within the organization. They do not know what they are doing becaue they got the job from a buddy instead of their performance. This does not apply to all managers. It does apply to the majority of them.

review_title: As long as you don't get caught up in any of the politics, an ok-place to work
pros: Generous and flexible work-at-home policy (although individual managers have the right to prevent your participation if they feel that it's "injurious to your ability to perform your function" (more likely, if they don't have to bother to pick up the phone when they want you for something).  With the right manager (I was fortunate to have an excellent one for most of my time there), you'll be allowed a great deal of autonomy not only in how you get your job done but also in how you shape the direction and nature of your job.
cons: Your boss's input on raises and bonuses will be treated by HR as "recommendations" and they will frequently block or greatly reduce incentives that your manager wants to pay you.  It seems to be worse at the corporate level than within the lines of business but, especially once you get to the upper salary bands, there seems to be a lot of pressure to relocate to Charlotte.  If you're not going to the same churches, country clubs and school plays as your boss's boss, your growth opportunities will probably be pretty limited...in spite of the stated work-at-home and "we're all connected" policies.  If you have different ideas for how to get things done, you may be able to implement them within your area but getting anything to happen at an enterprise level can be an exercise in frustration.

review_title: Do the right thing  but do more with less...and less.  At least on the mortgage side in fulfillment.
pros: Company values volunteering and believes in meritocracy.  Benefits (health, dental, 401K) used to be better but are decent but I assume all big companies are cutting in this area.  I had the ability to make a difference with my reporting group and to be on some challenging projects.
cons:
Initially when I joined, it was Countrywide and then later merged with Bank of America.  Prior to the merger the environment was very liquid, changes could be made quickly for dissemination of reporting.  Solid management.for the most part excluding a few bad apples.  Meritocracy at its finest, you were rewarded for your hard work and achievements.  After the merger, lots of growing pains but that is expected.  However post merger, departments became more silo-ed, communication issues  arose and company processes became very bureaucratic and slow.  Lots of management changes occurring multiple times a year.  Not to mention the now expected layoffs occurring every November, right before the holidays (It is almost becoming a tradition at BAC).  

I had the same manger for my first 7 years.  He was smart, saw the changes and decide to transfer to another group so he could retire on his own terms and not due to layoffs.  After that, I had a different manager each year for my last 2 years.  This change of management lead to micro-managing and leaders that do not fully understand the history of departments/reports/people that make it happen.  This led to the halting of support for areas outside of fulfillment such as sales and compliance.  

When new management takes over, they like to replace others with their own people.

pros: Great people throughout the office. No matter where I turn, people are there for help and guidance. Whether it be from lead and or colleague, there is plenty of positive vibes and help around the office. Plenty of room for growth within and it usually happens rather quickly if you have a sense of what you are doing.
cons: Salary and bonus are low initially, but they grow quickly once you move forward. If you aren't interactive and or satisfied with spending long periods of time on the phone, this isn't the place for you.

pros: Great benefits and easy to move around in the company as long as you are persistent. Pay was pretty decent and alot of fun working here
cons: The only con I would say is due to the mortgage crisis, you never know when or if you will be laid off. Job security is not good anywhere in the mortgage industry.

review_title: A balanced and positive environment to work in.
job_title: Fraud Analyst L and Ll in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Team leaders and managers alike show positive attitudes and maintain a balanced professional relationship with employees. Training is excellent and prepares you for the tasks at bay.
cons: The pay is lower than expected for such a large bank. There always seems to be an issue with transferring calls as far as the phone lines are concerned.

review_title: Used to be a good company to work at, but things have changed.
job_title: Vice President Technology in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Great Vacation and Paid time off.  
Company contributions to retirement account (401k and Pension) are pretty good. 
Benefits are good, but are being reduced each year it seems.
Work/Life programs and flexibility with work schedule is good, but being reduced. 
Access to computer based and web training training is above average.
cons:
Too many layers of middle management, which creates way too much administration. This makes it impossible to get the Real productive work completed without a lot of hours over the normal 40 hour work week. Also the layers of management do not always work together, so the entire company suffers with many wasted hours and project deadlines missed or projects going way over budget.
Many middle managers are not qualified. There are managers who were not good at the technical jobs they did previously and were never respected by their peers, but they were still given management positions. These managers would have the same peers working for them. The lack of respect doesn't goes away easy, so this is not the type of manager that would be successful long term and would not help the companies bottom line. A formula for failure and I have seen it destroy employee morale and team productivity on several teams.
Bonus program is pretty bad.
Health and Dental insurance keeps getting worse and employees have to pay more. 
The company keeps reducing its contribution to the employees retirement plans.
There are organization changes and Reorgs nearly every 6 months with Layoffs most of the time, so the employee morale is very low for many reasons.
They keep replacing IT jobs in the US with outsourced jobs overseas.

pros:
Team members made the work place fun
Get to know a few clients well. As a merchant teller this has its perks
Banking hours and holidays
Room to grow and advance in the company
cons:
Responsible for large transactions
Counterfeit bills and bad checks hinder future opportunities for teller not approving management 
Clients are rude
If you are not interested in finance it can be a tedious and draining job
Product sales play a major part in the job so if you are in a small branch or a Merchant teller who sees the same clients everyday it is almost impossible to hit sale goals

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Sherman Oaks, CA
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Strong Company with good values
- Upper management seems very concerned about the future direction of the company and is making efforts to go in a good direction.
cons: - Size. The company is really large. This could be a good thing but sometimes it leads to slow change in processes and the end customer experience could be turned negative due to the it.

job_title: Senior Teller in San Francisco, CA
pros: Perhaps a higher starting wage than other retail jobs, such as a clothing store.  More days off than typical retail stores, since they close for many holidays.
cons: A great deal of responsibility handling cash, but very little pay and huge pressure to sell to your customers.  Balancing your cash can is a basic minimum expectation, and selling products (credit cards, refinance, auto loans, new savings, etc) is constantly pressured upon you.  A lot of your performance reviews will equate to your sales.

job_title: Senior Funder in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Very good company to work for.  Lots of training, management support and communication.  Some room to grow.  Great beneifts!  Also, relatively easy to take time off.  I truly enjoyed working here.
cons: I did not like that employees had to pay for parking. Bank of America was in the process of consolidating offices when I left.  My office was slated for closure was to combine with the Pasadena office.  The Pasadena office has since closed as well.  Not sure how many offices are left in the area.

pros: Great team to work with and really good training. A little drama but that's what happens in a small environment filled with girls!
cons: Obviously a lot of politics with the upper management who showed up every now and then, ignored us, went into one of the offices and talked amongst themselves all day. Just a little uppity...

pros: Good benefits  pays OK OK if you're single mom
cons: Horrible management ,  favoritism  unrealistic expectations based on the  metric system in a call center environment incredible favoritism with management the unwillingness to assist an associate when they have problems

Competitive offerings

Continuously looking to improve offerings to clients and market position relative to risk tolerance
Management tries to do what is best for the group
cons:
Similar to other large banks, very process oriented
Art of deal gets lost in red tape
Given the size of the organization, it can be difficult to get things done and get assistance from other groups to best serve clients

review_title: Once a great company to work for
job_title: Vice President Finance in Charlotte, NC
pros: Vacation & sick time,  holidays, maternity/paternity leave
cons: Opportunity for advancement limited by new policies on minimum # of direct reports to be a manager, secrecy concerning policies, lack of transparency in personnel policies & pay scales, stacking of employees for performance ratings does not lead to fair or equitable ratings/bonuses

job_title: Home Health Aide in Saginaw, MI
pros: Very nice staff. Willing to work around scheduling conflicts. Full time for the right person. Pay is above average compared to other companies.
cons: Went in looking for an administrative position and accepted a position as an aide (I really needed a job). I have interviewed more than twice and have yet to land a job in the office.

review_title: Vice President, Consumer Product Strategy Analyst IV
job_title: Consumer Products Strategic Analyst IV in Newark, DE
pros: Flexibility, benefits, PTO are as would be expected by a large multinational financial services organization.
cons: Culture is strange.  People don't say hello to each other in the hallways.  They'll treat you like a complete stranger if they don't know you.  Senior Management has a mindset of "better than thou art".

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Orlando, FL
pros: Allows the opportunity to work part- time, no weekend hours. Pays well. Good benefits and employee discount program.
cons: Very sales oriented. Lots of pressure to meet referrals. Pushing the future of technology..we are very short staffed and over worked but they refuse to hire help because customers can use the atm or mobile banking instead of coming into our financial center.

job_title: VICE PRESIDENT, BANKING CENTER MANAGER III in Cambridge, MA
pros: Best in class technology.  24/7 customer access.  Pay and benefits are very good.
cons: Customer experience is not important except for the highly affluent.  Goals are not aligned with corporate initiatives, especially customer satisfaction goals.  Ivory tower mentality.

pros: There is room to grow at the company, it is a sales oriented company so you must be able to achieve desired numbers to grow but if you can reach said goals you can be rewarded .
cons: High-pressure jobs that require you to push yourself to reach said goals, must be good at working under pressure.

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Charlotte, NC
pros:
It is a very stable corporation with a lot of room for advancement.
There are many types of positions, there is a diversity of opportunity.
There are numerous facilities at which to work, so proximity is rarely an issue.
There is a very pleasant working environment.
cons: I am not sure I could really point out any major cons to working with or at Bank of America.  I rather enjoyed my time working there.

pros: God pay,  benefits,  training,  campus life. Management is really good.  Directors set a comfortable vibe. If you pass the exams, they help you really advance your career.
cons:
Working here has been an extremely stressful experience from the day that I got the call saying that I was going to be offered an interview. 
They need everything under the sun about your past, your background, your credit...... it's something they don't ask for your DNA to get the job. 
Even after you're hired, they're still harassing you for more background checks, more fingerprints, more credit checks and they will throw anything negative on your credit report up in your face randomly in the middle of the day and demand all kinds of written explanation as to why you didn't pay that debt. My case was a student loan payment that I had missed. 
Keeping the job is contingent upon the fact that you pass the beastly Series 7 Exam. The material is extremely difficult and they don't train you for it at all...they just throw you a couple books that are poorly written and extremely confusing, and a link to a website that is even worse.
The majority of people who work there don't even use the material that's how bad it is. They go off to use Kaplan. 
If you don't pass you get to take it again. 
Honestly the whole process of working there for the first 6 months is extremely stressful because you're constantly faced with the fact that you may not have a job much longer. This is the situation that just happened with me. 
I have 2 children, finally got hired at a company after about 2 years of a dry spell and the birth of a baby last year, and it felt so good to get my kids and I off of Medicaid and food stamps. I ended up not passing the exam with the demands from this job....the forced overtime and having to raise 2 children.
I didn't have the time that they require to study to pass this exam. I did bring it to their attention that there were a few sections that I needed extra help on that I didn't understand and they would offer help only to have it taken away because call volumes are more of a concern. 
As much as I tried I just wasn't able to get a successful score on the exam and now I am out of my job.
I have lost all of my insurance and I just got off the phone with the welfare office again because I need to have our insurance turned back on. I have a baby with a medical condition and we need to have him covered asap.
I was just about to go and get us a better apartment and now that's not going to happen. I think that this is an extremely cruel company and I think that that's a very horrible thing to do to somebody. They could have at least offered me another position or just kept me as a generalist. 

So basically the only way to make it at this position is if you're a young single male who lives at home and has no kids and no responsibilities and can devote all of his time to studying for this exam. Even when you go to this office and look around there's probably three women that work there and none of them have children. The rest of them are all young guys with nothing to do. The people that I did see leaving for not passing were in fact females with children. And it's sad because they push the fact they are all about women in the workplace.
Weekly you see the new herd of people coming in to replace the people that they're planning to fire.
How disgusting.

job_title: Customer Assistance Support Team/Auditor in Houston, TX
pros: The pay , benefits, and atmosphere was amazing!!!! I was able to move up in the business very quickly and made life long friends. When I was diagnosed with Stage 3 Ovarian Cancer right after I was promoted , my managers were very understanding and allowed me to continue my position after battling cancer. The health benefits allowed me to deal with cancer without having to worry alot about the medical bills!!! I miss working for Bank of America!
cons: I have absolutely nothing bad to say about working for BOA

review_title: Great company to work for as a teller.
pros: Great schedule. No stress. Any headaches get sent to an officer. All I worry about is balancing. No sales pressure. They offer childcare reimbursement, too!
cons: There really isn't a con. I could go on about how inefficient the operating software is but I think it's pretty great that that is all I can be negative about.

pros: Big company name for your resume and good benefits. Also great ability to relocate and can move into different LOBs.
cons: It depends on your branch, if you're at a slow branch you're screwed because you have the name metrics as a busier branch , and they want you to sell their way, not the way you sell best.

job_title: Vice President Technology Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Brand value in the market. 
Corporate culture and professional environment.
Allowed me to work from home until i left the company.
Highly ethical work environment.
Enjoyed working with many many talented professionals and business partners.
cons:
Heavily process oriented. Things move rather slow due to red tape.
For new associates, it would be a challenge to figure out who is who initially. 
They use many different tools for different jobs/processes and it could take a while to understand who is using what & why.
Way too many org changes every year.

pros:
Diversity
Can be hired with no degree
cons:
They have to hire so many people the quality of work from your co-workers can be pretty frustrating
They think nothing of moving mid-level backoffice jobs to India or moving whole entry level functions from site to site.  You are more of a resource than a human.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tampa Palms, FL
pros: Hours regular 8-4:30 M-F all holiday paid 11 total for a calendar year. Great PTO and benefits package. Structure of written policies and procedures.
cons: My department was a mess there was constant changes to executives and senior managers I reported to 3 different people in 8 month period and 2 the next year. Inconsistency from HR on how to deliver and give disciplinary actions. Other managers showed favoritism and special treatment to associates of choice. I was the only female and treated like a Secretary and not a team manager.

pros: The benefits were great. There was opportunity to advance as long as you knew the right people. The raises were good. Throughout the course of 3 years I got $4 total in raises, which working in retail that's better than some. All in all Bank of America was a good company.
cons: Not everyone wants to see you excel but that's every job. Management is not the best at all. I worked at 3 centers and each manager was completely flawed. Not really interested in managing the team but very interested in the quarterly bonuses.

pros: This role gives you a 12 month non recoverable draw to learn the business and establish a book of clients. This job is flexible your not on a set schedule and have freedom to go off-site to network and even work from home. Management is relaxed. Bank supplies phone lead source and retail location for leads.  Great benefits available.
cons: After 1 year possition is commission based with recoverable draw. Mortgage volume is unpredictable. Months of time where there is little to no business depending on market fluctuations and conditions.  Guidelines and document collection is always a source of frustration.  Expected to be in your retail location 3 to 4 days a week and at area office 1 day a week: pretty strickt considerig this is commission. Networking time is expected on weekends at open houses. This is a 40 hour work week on commission.  You will probably want to work 60- 70 hours to be sucessfull because there is never enough time.  But overtime is not authorized unless you are meeting production targets.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Middletown, NJ
pros: BOA likes to hire within, and encourage advancement. They are genuinely invested in their associates. I loved that my colleagues were from a diverse group.
cons: Sales sales sales.  There is a lot of micro managing.

review_title: Part Time Client Service Representative BOA
pros: Bank of America offers full benefits even for the part time employee. The company culture is amazing and the company really focuses on building relationships with customers from the ground up.
cons: Overall a Client Service Representative is just a fancy title for teller. The company can be strict on hours; therefore, it is hard to move from part time to full time teller and you must remain in your position for at least 12 months. Furthermore, the Client Service Representative position is strongly sales oriented and referral goals may be hard to meet.

review_title: Good Short Term Job Opportunity for 1-3 years
pros:
Plenty of work; never a dull moment. 
If you have a great manager, life is great.
Good place to gain skills in the financial services industry.
If Charlotte-based, many volunteer opportunities to get involved in the community.
Competitive pay upon initial offer.
Company is built on relationships. Everyone is always open to meeting for coffee to make new connections.
Great place to work for the experience for 1-3 years as the company has a strong brand.
cons:
Mid- to senior leadership are not skilled in the area that they work in. Lots of folks in Global Tech & Ops have no background in managing or developing technologies. Hard to be coached by someone not skilled in your functional area.
Too process focused and risk averse. Hard for anything to get done.
Layoffs are frequent. You never know when your time is up. 
Those laid off are based on if their managers like them and not based on the quality or value-add of their work.
Raises and bonuses are not guaranteed. I know plenty associates have not had an increase for years and the company bullies you to just be happy that you have a job.  
Overall, work morale is low.
If you have a bad manager, just flee as they are not looking for coachable moments to be a better manager.
Hard to get promoted if you are not a good networker and people person.
Lack of overall diversity, excluding white women.
No discount stock purchasing program.

review_title: No investment in talent management/career development
pros: Decent pay, good stability (except in IT), good work/life balance (though less work location flexibility than previously), lots of smart people, lots of resources. Performance does influence your compensation in your current job (if you have a good relationship with your manager & manager's manager).
cons:
Zero talent management, you are on your own to find new opportunities thru networking which means the people who advance are those who are highly skilled at networking and spend the majority of their time doing it, not people who are most skilled/best leaders. This self-serve process puts everyone who is not a straight CIS white man at a disadvantage and perpetuates the problem of lack of diversity in key leadership roles. Internal job boards are a joke, jobs are awarded thru networking. HR and recruiters will tell you one story about how to effectively manage your career, while managers keep tapping their networks to hire and everyone knows the process is for show.

Company has been pulling back on work from home program and consolidating workers to hub cities.

Company invests heavily in processes across the Bank - processes to get work done, to make decisions, to determine where budgets are invested; meanwhile,  most actual work gets done outside of process. Senior leaders make decisions in isolation and dictate them thru back channels and everyone scrambles to make it happen. To be successful you must be comfortable in a highly matrixed environment where the real rules are unwritten and processes are meant to be circumvented.

Company has aggressive head count reduction targets as works to gain efficiency (increase profits) thru technology. Increasing employee dissatisfaction may be a strategy to force FTE shedding without the bad PR of layoffs.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits such as health, childcare, educational the company also has a good match for 401k. This is a good company for someone starting as a teller. I wouldn't recommend for higher educated individual or professional.
cons: Bad management; no emotional intelligence, very selfish and greedy. Also, company is cutting staffing which upsets clients furthermore the clients take it out on employees.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Pay, some flexibility in working hours (depending on manager of the month), if you don't like your manager's manager, just hold in there, he/she will change in 6 months.
cons:
Nearly impossible  to progress your career. If you're ok going backwards, or sideways, or somewhere completely different to what you studied and worked to achieve, you may be happy. Skip level management turnover and reorganizations are constant - 6 skip level manager changes in 3 years, 5 major reorgs in 7 years. Bureaucracy in the extreme. Meetings that achieve nothing, but talk the same thing over and over. Lackluster and uninspiring 'leaders'. 'Leaders' is something that is revered - lots of do as I say, not do as I do and yet, there are countless typical large organization 'departments' or 'working groups' or 'focus groups' to hear your concerns and want to help you grow. And hear them again next year. And the following year.   
There's a certain BM direct that rules by fear and that trickles down the org chain. Result is, there is nobody who is willing to even try and manage up, we just go through the motions over and over again. 
Anyway, this is a typical large organization, and these cons are typical to a large organization. If you love this type of repetitive talk, meaningless meetings,  impossible to navigate 'network of advancement' (i.e., have been told repeatedly, don't expect to advance up, treat this like a monkey gym (what they heck?), and be prepared to work yourself down for many years if needed (while your .25% competency colleague who goes to the same church as whats his name, gets promoted to band 3 exec (put on your smile and congratulate him/her) and has everybody scratching their heads why).

pros: Great global team with which to be a part of, ever changing challenging environment, location strategy a big bonus if you’re not looking to move to London with bulk of the work moving up from London.
cons: Offshoring of production has left some junior roles very mundane, some uncertainty and lack of direction following Middle Office / Finance merger in 2017. Downside to location strategy is weak talent pipeline outside of London.

pros:
If you're going for a job at BAML you will probably know what to expect. Its a very corporate environment, and being such a big institution has its pros and cons. 

It is such a big company that each employees experience can differ.  I've spoke to countless employees, some liked their role, some hated it, some liked their manager, others hated theirs.

I have given the role 3 stars because being such a large institution it offers a lot and you can get a lot out of it but I didn't have the best experience. Though I recognise many other do. 

Generally good pay 
Good policy of hiring within and encouraging management to do this.  
Benefits are generally very good e.g. health care / lifestyle account was very good where you can claim back on activities you do such as concerts.
cons:
I didn't have the best experience but I feel this was down to a rather unrelenting role. Those that were in the role prior to myself didn't enjoy it, and my replacements also do not enjoy it. As it is role specific I won't go into detail.

More general criticisms/suggestions:

I was an analyst but I wasn't on the grad scheme yet was of a similar age - I could see the great opportunities they were afforded. It would be good for management to recognise that there are others working that are in the early stages of their career that would benefit from e.g. training, social events etc.. Ultimately, it is very unlikely line managers will care that much to put energy into the lower team members, and they shouldn't really be expected of them. 

More engagement and clarity with employees so that they know what they are entitled to so it is not at the discretion of management. It isn't just what should be expected from the employees, but what can the employees expect from management.  Management could be encouraged to aim to get a minimum quota of their team members going on development courses. This would encourage them to look into courses that would increase team members development specific to their role. In reality, I was in a small team with a very high workload. If you wanted to do anything within work time like courses you would be deterred by increasing your team members workload.

Ridiculous certificate scheme. I can't remember the issue but our whole team worked late for about 3 weeks in a row. As a reward we all got silver certificates which probably equates to £30 in vouchers. Pointless really. I'm not exactly going to be be hanging the certificate above my bed. 

Removed a few years back - fewer lower level employees in MO receiving bonuses.

review_title: Surrounded by great people, but incredibly stressful sales intensive enviorment
pros: In my case, I was lucky enough to be surrounded by great managers for the most part. One in particular, who was my direct supervisor and became a wonderful mentor for me. The pay was good, the benefits are very good. This includes an affordable insurance plan, and even child care reimbursement.
cons:
The biggest downside in my opinion was the high stress sales environment. I was essentially responsible for 50% of the sales production at our location and had some extremely lofty monthly/quarterly goals. The pressure is intense. I survived three years because of my manager and my ability to weather the storm, but this job is not for everyone. 

Also, working six days a week instead of five was a con for me. Even with limited hours on Saturday, having just Sunday off was a negative, and I didn't realize it until I moved on to another job. 

Another con would be it's incredibly challenging to move upwards unless you are starting as a teller. If you start at a mid-level position as I did, getting promoted can be a major hurdle, especially within your own branch. 

One of the other major cons is just the reality of where banking is at currently. Working for a company as polarizing as Bank of America was incredibly challenging at times. The news from many scandals and lawsuits really affects people's perception of you, and your ability to do your job at times. And then all the recent scandals with Wells Fargo, one of BoA's biggest competitors and another big bank only makes it that much worse.

pros: Got to meet great people, vacations were fair based on seniority, stuck around because they worked with my school schedule
cons: Back when I started in 2007, the manager made me take off a lip piercing because it didn’t look professional, which I thought was stupid but I couldn’t afford to lose my job! Anywho, now i see all these employees with tattoos and piercing and I wonder if there was some kind of discrimination. managers took advantage of us, overworked us. Made us do jobs that weren’t in our job description. A lot of favoritism.

job_title: Relationship Banker in Garden City, NY

cons: Career advancement  within the bank is really based on who you know rather than your own knowledge and inspite of being a top performer, I was not successful in achieving the next level. Trend was to hire younger people from outside. Face value became more important than brain value. I passed required assessments for the next two levels with excellent reviews but someone else was given the job.

review_title: A great firm on the up doing the right thing the right way
job_title: Senior Executive Recruitment Consultant in London, England

The bank although well placed still has significant opportunities for growth and market share which creates compelling opportunities for top talent.
cons: All the challenges of a large, highly regulated global firm. Complex operating environment, significant emphasis on consensus building, matrixed leadership model, decision making can become slow and bureaucratic at times.

job_title: Senior Account Specialist in Richland, WA
pros: The benefits were really good. Decent insurance and 401k plan. My team manager was great as well as my co-workers.  Looks good on a resume.
cons: I worked in a call center for the bank. The abuse from customers was rather shocking at times. The hourly pay wasnt great, it's sad when new hires are making almost as much as employees that have been with the company for several years.  I did training and mentoring for new hires and never received any additional pay. Having to make "quotas" on referals. Pushing customers to apply for products you know they either don't want or may not qualify for. Ever changing policies....things can change from day to day. Never knowing if you would have a job from day to day, as the bank has outsourced many of the call centers, which did happen in the call center I was employed by, now, if you have an account in the northwest, you will no longer be able to speak to someone in your area unless you call your local branch. Growth within the company was difficult. I excelled from "generalist" to "senior specialist" in about a year...however, once I obtained that position, I found that there was very little room to advance further.  I initially was excited about working for the bank...then after a while the glamour wore off and I was very disheartened by the direction the bank was going.

review_title: Strongly caution guidance on accepting work at Bank of America

review_title: Great benefits - Satisfaction depends on what you do.
pros:
Benefits are great.  
5% match on 401k. 
One paid volunteer day a month (subject to manager's approval).  
Work from home/flexible schedules for non customer facing jobs.
On the job training of most soft skills and quality certifications.
12 weeks of paid maternity/paternity (yes, even fathers).
Minimal travel.
Support/encouragement of distributed teams.
Stable/secure feeling most of the time (not the last few months).
Constant effort to improve process.
cons:
Lot of flux in the upper management (even before the recent (December '08) restructuring announcements, there is a lot of flux in mid level executives.  People constantly being moved around.  
Even though there is a great infrastructure and effort to keep "associates" up to date, such as using video on demand, internal website etc., critical decisions are still made in the traditional way (e.g. about job cuts).  The reports in business media seem to have more information than the internal websites when it comes to critical information.  But I guess that is understandable.
Lot of answers in the bank end up with "talk to your manager".  Which can be good or bad depending on your manager.
Most teams (in the back office) are over worked.  Few managers actually pay attention to great HR benefits like allowing a volunteer day.
Lot of internal fighting among middle management on "funding" issues.
Feels like consulting sometimes where associates have to find a  project to bill to.  Billing to the "base" is scary.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: Benefits are great if you can get hired. On site gym, cafeteria, covered parking garage to keep the AZ sun from ruining your paint.
cons: Dress code is silly by not allowing any other t-shirt unless it has a B of A logo on it. 30 minute lunch does not allow one to eat anywhere other than in the high priced cafeteria.  Temps still working in the building for over 2 years who have perfect attendance & great performance numbers.

review_title: Good management on the investment side, dealing with the banking side very difficult

Divisions of the company compete against each other for business!!! Huge potential for organic growth, but bank hasn't been able to successfully do it yet.

pros: There are many reasons - opportunities, good work environment, nice building, friendly coworks, good benefits, good compensation, forward mobility.
cons: Like with any other large corporation there can be a bit too much politics once in a while. Sometimes things take longer than they should to become a practice or formulate into a working model.

review_title: I really can't imagine it's as bad everywhere else as it is in Michigan, but it's miserable here.
pros: Promoted to full time, then a higher position within 2 years. Great benefits package, plus employee bonus rates on accounts, loans, etc.
cons: It seems as though we have something new thrown at us every morning; dress code changes (stricter to increase professional treatment scores), media buzz (how to defuse a customer who has heard media slander), new procedures, new performance measurements, a video on how great our company treats it's employees . . . you get the picture. It is the worst example of micromanaging I have ever experienced, leaving no room for creativity, sincerity, or true customer service. Advancement is possible, but only if you are willing to stay in a roll for a year regardless of your qualifications. Compensation for advancement is ridiculous, if not laughable, and we are constantly told to bare it all with a smile. Some days you want to walk out before the doors are even unlocked.  Like I said, it may just be Michigan, but if it's like this everywhere I don't know how they retain employees.

pros:

review_title: Puzzling bureaucracy and non equal treatment...
pros:
Less work compared to peers - so better work life balance. (If you end up in a wrong project - you can slog and still get paid much less compared to any competitors)

Investment banking division has a good brand name due to Merrill Lynch

Latest technologies like Python etc in work.. but depends on the project...
cons:
Employees are not treated equally - A similar employee in any other location other than India will be in one or two bands higher -
1) A senior analyst in India with 7 years experience is on Band 6 only whil-e a AVP in USA with 3 years of experience is on Band 5 - So when you want to travel from India to USA on business trip - you would travel in Economy class and stay in low cost hotels- while a fresh grad or anyone who travels to India from US/UK etc etc would always travel in business class and stay in Novotel, Westin etc..

2) The projects, quality of work etc are all driven from US - the main core is done there while the low end & non critical work is sent to India.

3) Fancy Management - All the management guys with fancy titles - AVP, VP etc in India are because they joined when the bank was setting up IT center and now the growth is completely stagnated.  People management skills are not there and micromanagement is encouraged and practiced , professed at each and every level of the organization that even a small presentation or a talk one gives you have to show and get approval from AVPs and VPs..!!

4) The policies are not at all employee friendly - for example the management doesnt encourage working from home and it is seen as a taboo. And only selected employees are given laptops - which are diskless - which means to connect to network  would take 25 mins everytime you want to just check a mail...

5) Facilities are sub-par  and basically the facilities team doesnt give a thought about any complaints 

6) Appraisal system is not a straightforward one as AVPs and VPs already decide a persons rating and ask a manager to rate the person accordingly and convince an employee.

7) Bonuses are not upto industry standards

pros: Free banking, close to home, good name company. I am sure working in the corporate environment would be a better experience than in the banking center.
cons: Your work experience in a small branch office is all about the manager. Unfortunately the way consumer banking is set-up, the local managers aren't closely monitored in how they manage their staff day-to-day. As long as the branch meets it's sales goals and the audits are good there is very little scrutiny. Our branch made it's goals and did well in the audit, but had high turnover due to the manager. While the manager was experienced and very good at many things, the management style was extremely dysfuntional. I felt like I was a child living in this person's house and had to follow their rules regardless. There were never 2 sides to a situation, it was always a "my way or the highway" mentality.  I had a very hard time with this, particularly with the lack of outside oversight. The manager is your real opportunity for promotion/visibility and if that relationship doesn't work you are toast. I have many friends that work in corporate jobs in the bank and love it. I am also sure other banking centers are awesome, I just didn't choose the right place for me. I would advise you interview your boss as thoroughly as possible and hope it works out!

pros: Bank of America has good hourly pay. The bankers do receive a lot of recognition. The benefits are fantastic. Tuition reimbursement is up to 5000 per year for all employees
cons: Very inconsistent with days off. The scripting is very robotic and redundant.  Additionally top performers do no get good bonuses.

pros: Good pay. Benefits seemed good although I was contracting at the time. It's a large company so there is a wide variety of opportunity, provided you can get to it.

review_title: Community minded organization with a lot of wheels in motion

Recent refocusing on the Customer experience and making banking simplier and straight forward.
cons: Large company with plenty of layoffs over the past few years. Not a lot of career direction assistance, it's every man or woman for themselves. Seems as though they would rather get rid of a top Associate rather than retrain and place elsewhere in the organization.

review_title: Contradicting goals and constant pressure for more sales
pros:
*Great learning experience, learn a lot about banking and business (also meant learning how companies are all about efficiency and profit, not much else)
*Provides excellent customer service
*Some GREAT co-workers with very nice personalities
*Benefits (medical, dental, vision, retirement, tuition reimbursement...)
*BOA stays on top of the game, embracing technology advancements
cons:
**Experience depends A LOT on management
*The core values this company says they stand for are awesome, but in reality BOA does not operate according to values, only what brings in the money
*I have heard employees who have been at BOA for over 30 yrs expressing how they would get out if it weren't for their families because of all the changes made and how stressful and sales-oriented the company is becoming. Heard this is the worst 1.5 yrs of their career in banking
*Employees must be extremely flexible while expected to deal with very inflexible management
*Very strict on scheduling hours, not going overtime (will give exactly min. required hrs only)
*Sales, sales, sales... contradictory statements like "It's not about the numbers! It is about making a positive difference in our customer's financial lives!" and then grilling us about how we need more checking more checking more credit card more referrals
*Sudden changes without much explanation which leave employees without much to say to angry customers
*Employee scores depend on factors they are not able to control, numbers assigned to everything, leads to finger-pointing because SOMEONE needs to be blamed
*Very hard to work for a company that is so hated... very angry customers who come in and scream about how they hate BOA. We are supposed to give excellent customer service but management makes you practically kiss the ground the customer's walk on.
*You are just someone people come to yell at if you're at a banking center, you are just a number, a tool producing numbers who will get fired if you do not make a difference in sales, no matter how much they say that banking is about customer experience
*Starting to separate services between rich and poor people, making exceptions and giving different treatment to those with money
*Market managers being so intense they are literally known for making people cry from being intimidating and playing mind games
*Cutting jobs and dumping them on current employees, more work with less people for efficiency, though the extra tasks they assign do not mean more time or more money for employees who are doing the work
*Not a transparent company at all, so much work put into manipulating customers, tons of scripting that doesn't actually say or mean anything
*Your voice will not be heard, employees afraid of saying anything that goes against management or do not bother because they know it will not make any difference

review_title: BAC has improved much over the past years, proud to work for them now.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Westlake Village, Optional[CA]
pros: Flexible work hours and nice facilty

Real bankers with experience don't have a chance in certain line-of-business due to this practice by ex-Countrywide employees.  It's not what-you-know, but rather who-you-know and if you're a relative needing employment despite your career background.  Very few Team Leads know their line-of-business that they are leading.

job_title: Sales & Service Specialist in Port Orange, FL
pros: Benefits, paid vacation, health insurance, paid sick days, tuition reimbursement (if you can find the time and your supervisor approves).
cons: Promotions happen based on favoritism, I witnessed this firsthand. High level of stress, very sales driven (cross selling other departments products or referring as they call it). Work/Life balance is almost non existent. Also, management seems very quick to place the blame on others to cover their own buts something I also witnessed first hand. Also I noticed a abnormal proportion of men/women in my line of business (95% women) all the way up to the market manager level. Also something that I personally witnessed was when we were 2 weeks away from the end of the quarter and had already hit our goal the company decided that they were going to raise our goals higher. Of course no one hit that goal which resulted in the branches not getting their payout. Thats pretty shady stuff right there if you ask me.

pros: Good benefits, good 401k, most departments have a great work life balance.
cons: Everything about this job is bad! There is a training class every 2 months due to the fact that associates do there year and leave as soon as they are eligible. Bank of America strategically takes customer out of the automated system solely to sell them additional credit cards, balance transfers, and direct deposits, 7/10 customer will be upset about this and ask you "Why am I talking to you, I just want to make my payment/ get my balance?" Customers just want to activate their card or inquire about their balance and we are trained to keep customers on the phone long enough to try to set up the sale, very sleazy and uncomfortable interaction with customers when this is your job. You will need to have good sales and analytical skills but even more so LUCK because most customers will be short and want to end the call ASAP, managers will always be on you about hitting sales quotas, even when you do get the sale they will coach you on how you should've offered customers another credit card or got them into more debt and upsold a direct deposit into their checking account. We're just getting over the whole mortgage crisis and we are pushing debt onto the customer! The hours are bad and the days off are split during the week, if you have a family and are use to 8-5 schedule you will have a hard time adapting to the crazy hours you will have to work. Bank of America is a great company and I would recommend you look at opportunities at the bank but if you see this job posted my advice...wait until you see something else, I'm pretty sure you will regret it.

pros: Large company, lots of great people, opportunities to learn, excellent benefits. Bank of America hires truly wonderful, caring individuals who work very hard. Local leadership and trainers are exemplary.
cons: Some of the local managers are extremely unprofessional and rude. Executive leadership (NOT local on-site) gives a lot of lip service to providing great customer service, but does NOT provide the tools to the every day associates in the contact center to make that happen.
