This in itself is why so many have left B of A in the past few years.

pros: Great hours and pay is pretty darn good for the job deacription. Employee appreciation days laid back finally got a job where I don't feel stressed
cons: Dealing with needy customer's and listening to complaints about everything all day for 8 hours. Job is pretty repetitive and gets old after a while.

pros: there are a lot of good people who make every effort to complete their work according to the standards provided
cons: There are a lot of management that are put into position for political and not actual work experience reasons.  the work load can be unrealistic and what feels like arbitrary policies and procedures.  starts to feel like working for the government

pros: generous employee benefits, good vacation time, opportunity to learn multiple new skills and apply them on the job, opportunity to work with and learn from very diverse fellow employees with different backgrounds
cons: Like other companies, quality of work/life balance depends on the department you work in. Managers everywhere should listen to employee feedback and really think about suggestions offered from the 'front line.'

job_title: Consumer Product Strategy Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Strong work ethic of peers, process oriented environment, great benefits.
cons: A lot of red tape in the recent years with a culture that has shifted to be more reactive than proactive in recent years. Understandable given recent environment with regulatory agencies imposing audit findings and fines.

pros: Bank of America truly is a bank of opportunity.  There is an abundance of resources at your disposal to help meet your needs and reach your personal and professional goals.
cons: I know this may seem bias but I can't think of any cons with Bank of America that you wouldn't find in any other large corporation.

pros: I loved getting paid holidays, and the hours are probably the best out there.  Most locations are only Monday-Friday with weekends off.
cons: Management is awful.  They push sales sales sales.  They have no regard for the customers, or the employees. They made it difficult to go to school even though I only worked part time.  They refused to work around my school schedule.  They want to bleed the customers of money and more products. Most of the time, the products aren't a good fit.  They lie about being customer oriented.

job_title: Senior Vice President, Consumer Product Strategy Manager II in Goodyear, AZ
pros: A lot of good people and the ability learn. Tons of free learning available, all that is needed is a willingness from the individual. If you have banking or financial services background you can be successful at the bank
cons: Consumer Operations is tricky and unstable. If you are not willing to be flexible the bank is not for you . Change is inevitable and a part of the culture. there is nothing static . this can be a pro or a con. But it is something that is important and a part of the expectation.

review_title: They care more about reputation than employees
pros: The pay is decent....they used to have a work from home program which was nice, but has since  been abolished.
cons: They won't evict families from their homes over the holidays but will layoff a bunch of employees 2 weeks before Christmas.  I was escorted to a conference room by someone I didn't know....laid off by 2 men I didn't know while the dept head whose office was right next door to the conference room I was in, hid out with the door closed.  VERY LOW MORALE.

pros: Vacation time is amazing, they have a nice cafe inside of the call center, and the money is okay.
cons: Schedule changes like the weather, associates are constantly cursed out because their cards are blocked, stressful environment, constantly competing with peers, and everyone's depressed.

pros: Work with Node.js, grunt and yeoman to create awesome responsive websites. Laid back atmosphere as long as you finish your work. Flexibility to work from home (sometimes).
cons: Agile organization constantly attacked by scope creep and an abundance of grooming meetings (3-5 per week). Currently in a hiring freeze. Lack of personal space. Lack of want to improve by most other developers ("This is they way we always do it" mentality).

review_title: Good routine job and good pay
pros: Good pay, easy to learn, good team work and spirit, great company benefits, opportunities to move positions, banks. I didn't have work stress when I left work.
cons: Sometimes the personal bankers and the tellers worked "separately." Seemed as there were two cliques. We had a tough micro manager which made our work environment uncomfortable. It also became about sales or making the referrals.

pros: I enjoyed the team I worked in the financial center and for the most part, I enjoyed interacting with my clients.
cons: First and foremost, it is important to know that this a sales role. Unfortunately, in many of the branches, the goals are simply unattainable. This is problematic because not only do you not fund if you don't make goal, you'll also get written up and eventually terminated. You'll find that your success in this role depends much more on which branch you have been in than on your ability to sell. Although management will never admit it openly, they are aware that goals aren't realistic. That won't stop them from writing you up. When you're hired, you're told that with bonuses, you could be making $80,000. I'm not sure if this is true because I don't know anyone who has made their goal. Work-life balance is problematic because you are required to work six days a week.If you're lucky a may get one Saturday off a month. It depends on who your manager is and what staffing is like in your branch. However, because it is an hourly position and this company is very anal about overtime, you work less than eight hours a day to make up for the hours you work on Saturday. Expect to have to cold call people to try to make appointments for them to come in so you can sell to them. This is doubly frustrating because not only are you not allowed to sell on the phone, you have to deny that the call itself is a sales call in order to comply with regulations. The call are recorded, so if you miss something, your manager will know soon and you'll be in violation of regulations. This used to be a great company to work for.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Very thorough training. Good environment. Everybody seems happy here and it is a good company to work for. I would highly recommend bank of America and their training program
cons: Training can be looked at as too extensive. A lot of computer work and little role play. Have to work Saturdays which can be a problem for some people as it is a 6 day work week.

pros:
- Work at one of the largest banks around.
- Get experience with huge (not big, huge) data
cons:
I never felt as though senior leadership had an idea of how to utilize me. I spent most (probably 95% of my time) surfing the Internet for non-work related things. For the first several months I worked at Bank of America, I asked at least twice a week for more work. And after those several months and receiving nothing in return, I stopped asking. I only started receiving assignments once I reached the final two months of my contract.

The vice president I worked under was never very clear in what he wanted out of my work, so I was left asking for more direction or just providing any and everything I could think of and then watching as 80% or so would get hacked out.

Networking within the company is not very well fosteted. It's a very large company so some of this is to be expected, but I feel as though I'm leaving after working with maybe three people. Many days, I said more to the security guards down in the lobby on my entry and exit than I did to anyone on my team, and the most I said to those guards was "hello" and "have a good night." And I'm generally a friendly and talkative person. 

Getting an audience with any executive level people is like pulling teeth. And this is not by their efforts, but rather the fact that their calendars are booked 100% at the start of the week. To get time with them, you have to schedule a meeting at least two weeks out.

job_title: Senior Manager Applications Development in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great salary, bonus, perks.  Lots of opportunity for advancement or shifting careers (i.e. marketing to product development or software engineer to architect or network engineering).  Opportunity for expanding skillset and education (e.g. six sigma program, executive leadership program).
cons: Too many acquisitions has caused the company to constantly be in flux.  You will see a new department head change almost every year or two.  Very rapid work environment, if you're not careful you will find yourself working nights and weekends.  Six Sigma environment (extremely matrixed) that's a pro and a con.

review_title: Your satisfaction depends on your role
pros: If you're working in their Python platform called Quartz, you'll generally be pretty satisfied. The Quartz Core team are generally good people who are open to input.
cons:
You can expect to see senior management change as much as twice a year. Although once every couple of years is typical. Regardless, your manager's manager is rarely around long enough for their plans to really get to an end result. "Work in progress is the silent killer." is the appropriate tech quotable here.

Also, THE SOLUTION TO HAVING FIVE THOUSAND TICKING SYSTEMS IS *NOT* *ANOTHER* TICKETING SYSTEM!!!!! Pick one, make everyone use it. EMEA non-prod changes go in one ticketing system, EMEA prod in another, AMRS non-prod goes into the same one as EMEA's prod, AMRS prod goes into something else. Need a new laptop? That's entirely separate ticketing system. Need to access NAS or SAN from a workstation? That's yet another ticketing system. Need the same NAS or SAN from a QA server? Yup. Different ticketing system. Firewall request? Yet ANOTHER ticketing system and one that requires you to pass training and you better not forget to open the second ticket that works in parallel with the firewall ticket or otherwise you'll have that ticket canceled and you get to wait another 3 weeks while you wait to be told what's wrong with your NEW tickets ........... I could go on.

pros: Mostly good managers, everything was above board, benefits were decent. They warn you far in advance if layoffs are coming, and help you transition or find other work. Relatively little to no drama in the working environment, and usually no unwelcome surprises like forcing people to work overtime.
cons: Pay was not competitive at all, no perks besides the pay and benefits. Some individuals did not get much advanced warning of their layoff. Stale company culture. If the compensation wasn't so bad, I would recommend this company.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Hopewell, NJ
pros: Great way to get your licenses and nice introduction to the industry. Awesome coworkers who make coming to work every day bearable.
cons: Everything else. You are a product pusher, not a financial advisor. You're not building your own book and maintaining relationships causing advisors to not care at all about helping the clients. The confusing comp system is designed to not pay you for your work, and you have to challenge for work you've already done. It's a call center, be prepared to take lunch only during your assigned lunch time; they treat you like you're in kindergarten and don't value employee input.

pros: The starting salary, incentive pay, paid time off and benefits are very competitive.  Nice campus.  Friendly atmosphere.  Experience with HR department on initial hire was great.
cons: The training does not adequately prepare new employees for the position.  Lots of wasted time. They claim that employees should do what is best for the customer...but there is a lot of pressure to make sales.  Quality monitor scores and customer satisfaction surveys are expected to be close to perfect..if not you will lose your incentive at best and at worst be terminated.  There is A LOT of use of the word "fail".  Overall the regulations and management  ensure a very negative and unpleasant work environment.  Calls are back to back and they require that you account for EVERY minute you are not available to take calls.  There is no " assist" line to call if you have a question. Other associates try to be helpful, but ultimately you are required to look everything up in their online manual while the customer waits and the manual is difficult to navigate. Worst call center environment I have worked in.  Actively looking elsewhere.

pros: Benefits are awesome, plenty of ability to move internally and develop new skills.
cons: If you have any notions of advancing beware, HR is absolutely on the side of the groundfloor worker and your team make life very difficult making jumped up accusations. I not only had to deal with this myself but personally know plenty of leaders who have been "let go" because of vindictive teams members. it's almost impossible to fire an employee because of their byzantine disciplinary process.

review_title: Stressful and constantly fearing for your job
pros: The training is extensive - 10 weeks. Plus the hourly rate is really good and the hours and holidays are obviously a plus.
cons: Your direct manager isn't in the branch, they're a market manager and you don't hear from them unless you aren't making the numbers they want. All they care about is selling products. Sell sell sell. But don't miss a conference call and don't work over time. You're just a number to the company. They make the job sound like you're actually going to help people but it's just a sales manager position and they let you know that they're constantly hiring people to replace those who aren't making the market managers money. Too stressful and too much pressure.

review_title: Bank of America - Personal Banker Job Review
pros: Helps develop a foundation for team work and also good for developing leadership skills, even from lower level positions.
cons: On the low end of pay compared to other major US Banks. They ask a lot of every employee but do not compensate properly according to their demands. Many branches lacked strong and qualified leaders around the time I was there.

pros: Great benefits, many locations, and this company actually gave me a lot of experience to put on my resume, since I was moved to different positions almost every year. If you can get your foot in the door, it could be a good place to start your banking career.
cons: Serious lack of formal training. New hire training had nothing to do with the actual job, and lack of training in every other position I worked in. Very minimal activity to boost moral. Pay doesn't stack up to other banks in the industry. The end of year review and raises were always a joke. I started in collections, but the company has been laying off since I started in all different areas, so we have been moved from one position to the other. I have worked in 6 different positions in my 7 years at the bank, which can also be somewhat of a good thing. I love change, but when you can't train on what you're changing to, it makes it sort of difficult, since the company is very much production based. I researched a lot, as well as other team members, and 4 of these 6 positions were very high paying opportunities, but because we were moved to them on a lateral level, we did not get any kind of pay increase or merit increase. No compensation at all, so I was getting the same amount I was making as a collector, when I was doing a completely different, more high level role. I just really did not like the way they went about doing things here. In my opinion, the company had poor management and a very strange way of doing things.

review_title: Good job to have as student or starting career
job_title: Client Service Representative in San Mateo, CA
pros: Nice staff, benefits are solid, lots to learn, pay is slightly better than average. Products are easy to sell. Very inclusive culture thought it may seem a bit forced at times.
cons: The actual work itself is rather tedious/repetitive. You eventually get tired of cashing checks for people. The company is good, the clientele poses a bit of an obstacle sometimes. Glorified retail essentially.

review_title: Too Many Climate Changes and Empty Promises
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fort Worth, TX
pros: There are great medical benefits and they always find a reason to feed you.
cons: They will hire large training classes for a specific position or department and then completely change that position or merge departments. Learning new things is not bad, but I personally had to move from chats to phones and my success plummeted.

review_title: Not a real "FA" job. May be good for personal bankers.
pros: You can get licensed here and go elsewhere. They will pay you to study!
cons:
If you think this role is about being a financial advisor look somewhere else. I would use this firm to get licensed and leave.  The role of FSA is a glorified banker role which entails opening credit cards and savings account (this is where most fsa's get their new money) 

All the company cares about is referring to other lines of business. They stress stuff that will make the company money and you won't see a dime from it.

pros:
I'm very grateful that they worked with my school schedule when I was a student even though my schedule will often change each quarter. That's one of the main reasons why I stayed with Bank of America during my college years.
This job was a good stepping stone to find a better opportunity and really made me very detailed-oriented and developed my communication skills.
cons:
Tellers are very micromanaged. They are expected to have a certain % of referrals and they track that with pen and paper throughout the day which is very annoying, especially when the majority of customers walking into the banking center are there for one specific purpose and don't really have the time to sit down and have other products be sold to them.
I very much hated that vacation had to be picked earlier during the year and no two people from the teller line could take the same week off. So because you picked based on seniority, those who hadn't been with the bank for a long time always had the leftovers and often times, the weeks available for choosing really sucked. Also, you could never pick your 2 weeks together... just horrible!

Pay was also very low compared to other banks and the fact that they're trying to reduce tellers due to establishing new machines really makes customers angry. And when you're dealing with people's money and they're already mad at the line and wait time, it just makes matters worse.

Another point, they never show appreciation as  a company for their employees. Not even a Christmas party was ever offered or special lunches to celebrate their top sales or top employees. These would often come from the pocket of the financial center manager, not from the Bank, ever.

review_title: I have met great people, but there is zero loan officer future.
pros: The only Pros working as an FCLO is working with fellow employees across business platforms.
cons: The managers in Maryland only know how to lead by making threats causing huge morale issues. Ask any local loan officer. We are told to take leads we just recieved from the bank and send the lead back to the branch so the lo officer numbers look good, totally fabricated. The managers show favoritism and will tell every LO that their branch is the best when the managers have no clue. Get ready for a big game of politics and micromanagement.

review_title: Used to love it here. Then BOA went downhill.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Providence, RI
pros: Quality health, dental, and vision. Parental leave, childcare reimbursement, tuition reimbursement, short and long term disability, 3wks vacation 2wks sick, decent pay rate, discount programs, onsite gym.
cons:
I worked for a Preferred client call center. Other areas of the bank may be better. Like states they have awesome benefits and pay decent. However the call center is terrible and you feel like you’ll never advance. It’s a rat race. 

Over worked, understaffed, highly micromanaged, limited room for advancement, bonuses can be a joke, verbal abuse daily from entitled customers, opened for holidays when that’s not what I was hired for, time off impossible to get for many days, overly strict attendance, too much grey area in policies, lack of communication with changes, policies that don’t work.

I worked with the bank for almost 5 years. My last 2.5 yrs were terrible. I kept holding out as management promised it would “get better.” I finally stopped holding out hope and jumped ship and honestly I couldn’t be happier. My mental health and happiness has skyrocketed. BOA really made me miserable. 
Call hold times at 90 minutes but they want us to have 100% customer satisfaction, all while pushing customers off the phone and do as little as possible to meet metrics for call time. 
Policies aren’t black and white and what they will do for the screaming crazy person to shut them up, they won’t do for the long time client who deserves it. 
Quality fails people for the tiniest things. 
If you need to use the bathroom outside of your break time it’s an issue. I was told to take time off my break, which is illegal. 
They started adding more skills and requirements to our job but didn’t increase pay rate. 
There is an extremely high turn over rate, with many long term employees leaving as well, you would think management would get a clue.

review_title: Very disorganized and a little dishonest
pros: There are some smart people who work here and kind people as well. The benefits are on par with your average large corporation.
cons:
Lack of onboarding for new employees on certain teams. Be prepared to be thrown into the work in most situations with little to no context of what has been going on before you started. 

The interview process was not transparent and that was made apparent when I started the job. After almost a year, my manager is still trying to obtain buy-in on my scope of work but I was made to think it had already been obtained during the interview. 

This has led to me solely being a “helper” for my team and helping them with tedious work when they’ve hit capacity. 

Also, poor collaboration. Many people have carved a comfort nitch for themselves and take advantage of others so they don’t see an increase in work. That is why you’ll hear about people being here for 20+ years. Either they’ve lucked out and ended up on the rare good team or they’ve carved a lane out of not actually producing and using their seniority to pawn work off on newer team members. 

As for benefits, don’t expect to work from home even though that made be sold to you during the interview. I was told the company monitors badge usage and will ping your manager after working from home too many times. This results in a ton of micromanaging and fear in the culture so employees value being visible over actually producing good work.

I really wish I could share more positive sentiments but they truly have been few and far between. If coming from a smaller organization, this may still be a good fit but if you’ve worked at other large companies with decent workplace cultures, I would avoid BOA.

job_title: Client Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Great benefits and associates are well connected.
cons: No work-life balance- the business put clients over associates,  demands too high

job_title: Senior Relationship Manager in Dallas, TX

cons: Not a lot of career growth in Middle-Market commercial banking as a Sr. Relationship Manager.  Only 2 Market Executive positions in DFW.  Lack of understanding of emerging markets and VC backed technology companies.

job_title: Vice President Senior Small Business Banker in Midwest, WY
pros: Work life balance, benefits, flexibility, incentive pay. Room for growth and upward mobility. Technology, provided with the tools to succeed.
cons: Micro management, job is consistently changing, management who have never worked in small business, expect way too much and have no idea what they are doing. Way too much focus on metrics and not on client relationship and closed sales. Way too political-always about who you know vs what you know.

review_title: In general a great company. Not a great role.
pros: Company perks and benefits are top notch. Vacation and sick time is generous and there are many resources for employees. Great hours if working in a financial center and holidays are paid. Management was overall very pleasant but very sales driven.
cons: The relationship manager role is not one I would easily recommend. The salary is higher than similar roles at other financial institutions but you are micro managed every single cent. Your opinion does not matter and selling bank products is the only thing that matters. The company has a saying "we are making financial lives better through the power of every connection". You will constantly be told that you are there to help clients financial lives and find what is most important to them. In reality the sales goal is all that matters even if you are able to help a client budget or give some savvy financial advice that does not matter because a sale was not made. It is a culture of smoke and mirrors, doing good is hidden behind selling products. This financial institution does not care to lower income clients in any way, shape or form. Working in a low income area will make this role even more difficult. The company pushes credit, credit, credit. It is the only solution that really matters. The recruitment process was very misleading as to what the role would actually be. If you like cold calling hundreds of bank clients in order to get them in front of you and sell them a credit card then this job is for you, the job is sold as a golden opportunity and the turn over is very high.

review_title: Be very sure you want to work for Bank of America

review_title: Bank of America: The best consumer bank; the worst back office.

pros: Work life-balance, experience, diversity, and the people.  That said, it would be accurate to say the only thing that needs work is monetary compensation. It is really good for employees with families, not so much for ambitious single folks.  New employees get 3 weeks vacation.  There is also a $3,000 reimbursement if you buy a hybrid car, and $5,000 per year for tuition reimbursement.  There is also a lot of women and minorities in the workplace, more that anywhere else where I have worked.  Considering the company’s challenges with regard to pay, it is shocking to see the talent and quality of people that they have been able to retain.

The bank really puts a lot of value in job changes within the company, especially if it’s in the same line of business.  The only time you will see a big (big defined as greater than >15%) pay raise is when you switch jobs.  The whole idea, from the Bank's perspective, is to get people in at the lowest possible salary.  Then begin to get those recruits training and additional experience.  After that, the burden of salary increase falls squarely on the employee to take control of the career path to gain increase in salary through lateral moves and promotions. cons: Paid for my Bachelor's Degree and did not allow me to work for them in Civil Engineering capacity due to lack of experience.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Depending on which team and which manager you're under, you can have a tremendously rewarding or a going nowhere career! I was fortunate to have worked under and worked with some of the brightest minds at BAML and have really appreciated the respect, visibility and opportunity that was presently to me
cons: Employees at the very bottom of the chain should be looked at and their grievances should be heard out. Many managers just are too controlling sort of nature.

review_title: More of Outside Sales than initially communicated
pros: You get some leads from the bank. Not enough for a career for sure. Fairly good insurance and benefits. You can get tuition reimbursement.
cons: You will starve if you only have those bank leads. Also, realtors will shy away since it is a big bank. So it's not very possible to build business.

pros: Good hours, good pay, goes out of its way to take care of its employees, makes you feel like you 're part of a family, great benefits, opportunity for career growth, good work-life balance,
cons: Positions at all levels can be very unstable, but this is probably true of banking in general.  Don't allow yourself to get too comfortable in a position and expect it to last forever.  Be pro-active in seeking out new opportunities within the bank.  Lots of new roles open up continually.

pros: Decent benefits but better are available with other banks. Stable work environment and good mid-level management. Hires quality people so coworkers are usually quality people.
cons: Typical corporate money mongers. Care more about sales then benefiting clients. Negative account? Oh, take a credit card! Make your life even worse! Coming in to talk about a deceased relative? Sorry, I still have to push products on you and Hard-sell or I’ll be in trouble.

pros:
- Benefits to include vacation time and child leave
- Salary for the most part is good
cons: - Little mobility within the company to change career paths for the majority of people, meaning if your are in the retail banking sector it is very hard to do something outside of it. It is what you make it like with anything else, but the politics are very real and the opportunity to network outside your line of business is incredibly limited.

review_title: Good benefits, culture, work; lacking career development/training
job_title: Risk Analyst Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Work is interesting, people are generally very friendly, reasonable hours and expectations. Not political; can definitely move up.
cons: Many of our employees were shuttled downtown effectively isolating our team from the rest of the bank. There is a general lack of effort to both educate and care for their employees' financial education and career aspirations. It feels as if they are  suffocating our growth.

review_title: Only for people who like to do usual stuff !!
pros: Good Benefits like free Transport, Food , Drinks (Tea or coffee in Machine)
cons:
* No career Advancement, it takes Ages to get promoted, to be eligible for Promotion takes 3 years and on top of that your leads should be fine with your Promotion else you have to wait indefnitely
* No role/Technology changes within the Company
* Working on old Technologies that are not used anywhere in the market
* Too much Office politics in Chennai offices
* HR Team is a joke, they are there getting free salary and commisions from consultancy firms, they dont take candidates through internal referral as they wont get commission or bribe from consultancies

pros: Good incentive structure, reasonable goals, management tried to make work enjoyable. Benefits and PTO were great. Show your talent and you will be promoted quickly.
cons: Some of the “processes” were not profitable and as a sales job it didn’t make sense. Tracking the same information 3 places which is time consuming and is never used, always seemed like busy work.

pros: The hours are great. The potential for commission each quarter is super great.  The healthcare benefits and rewards program are unmatched. They promote from within. Training is extensive and information. Pay is good when compared to other financial institutions
cons: MICROMANAGED ALOT!!!!.  Too much emphasis is placed on numbers more so than the clients real interest. MANAGERS will pressure you each and every day via email and phone calls about doing better at surveys or deposit growth.

pros:
401K matching
Salary 
Best Benefits 
Job Mobility 
Stock price steadily increasing
cons:
Some departments are better than others when it comes to Management and depth of knowledge.  Great thing there are many jobs, but's best to become a subject matter expert in that dept and work your way up or have the knowledge and build connections to learn about your next career move whether it's the finance or banking side.
Some areas are more stressful than others due to the risk and potential loss.

pros: Very manageable work life balance. Lots of time for internal networking.
cons: The program is much more reporting heavy than led on, with most challenging roles moved to NYC. Most positions in the program only keep analysts busy for 1-2 weeks a month, leaving much more to be desired.

review_title: I have been working here for more than 8 years
pros: Great benefit and fair pay
cons: Loan processors here handle lots of works including review and clear conditions, which should be Underwriter job. Processors are not just processing loans but also ensure to meet customer services at high rate. Normally goal is for each processor to close 20 -30 loans per month and cycle time of each loan from loan application date till funding date is within 40 days. Also customer rating should be 9 or above from scale 1-10. Pipeline for each processor is about 30-50 loans.

pros: Great benefits!  Promotes volunteering and giving back to te community.
cons: No loyalty. No money for those that advance within. You have to leave and return back in order to make what you deserve.

pros: many office-type roles can be carried out wherever there’s an Internet connection. Stay at home, pop to a café, rent a co-working space, go live in another country if you like – as long as you’re not scheduled to be somewhere with a client, it’s completely up to you.
cons: Freelancing requires a certain degree of self-motivation. If you don’t have the get-up-and-go to chase jobs, or are just a bit lazy, you’re going to earn less. And it’s a lot harder to enjoy acres of free time when you’re worried about cash.

pros: Great culture, tech driven, customer management built platform
cons: Not enough tellers, you would see 6 windows open and 1 teller taking long lines.

review_title: Bank of America, a place to work
pros: You are surrounded by high quality professionals who are strong performers in their field.  People are willing to share their experience with you.
cons: At times there can be a lack of work life balance and a lack of recognition that things don't always happen overnight without tremendous effort.

pros: if you like to help people and enjoy sales work then its a great job to have but the salarie makes it hard to make a living.
cons: because every dept. has sales goals they inadvertantly pit each other against each other and throw other depts under the bus so to speak.

pros: You can work here if you just want to get your foot in the door and need the work experience to build on your resume.
cons: This company doesn't commit to their core values. The term "Meritocracy" is a joke. Promotions and job transfers go to cronies and incompetents. Their idea of balancing work & family is mandatory overtime & working on Saturdays. Don't stay here if you're looking for a rewarding and meaningful career.

pros:
-It's a good place to have on your resume if you ever want to go to business school or just a better paying job at a different company.
-My team was great to work with.
cons:
-Pay could be higher.
-If you're looking to get paid like other investment banks, you can forget it.
-It's hard to move from one specialized division to another.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Employer reputation and range of positions offered over the platform are extensive and thorough.  The bank covers the better portion of the US market and provides a lot of job security.
cons: Red tape and politics dominate the platform, as is the case in most industries.  Granted this commentary is with regard to one part of a very large platform, which can also be a hindrance.

pros: Coworkers in ebusiness are very bright, good people working on important, interesting projects.
cons: Every workplace has difficult issues now. The BofA ebusiness departments are not that bad, though the level of micro-management there is remarkable and enough to make it really hard for people to communicate and understand bigger-picture changes. There is a huge cultural divide between the Charlotte and San Francisco teams.

pros: I got time off when i needed. Great benefits. Great company. Always a chance for commission.  Good work clarity. Room to advance. Can switch departments at any time. So many different department that you can stay with the bank and do different things.
cons: Had to deal with annoying customers. Not the highest paying job. Harder work than you got paid. Alot is expected of a PB

review_title: Disappointed after MBNA became B of a
pros: No paperwork, nothing to take home, job is an assembly line where you show up and clock in, and clock out at the end of the day leaving it all behind.
cons: Its sometimes a dirty job where you are forced to sell expensive products that dont necessarily help the customer. ouch.

review_title: Experience was terrible due to acquisition of Countrywide.
pros: It is a big company so there is opportunity to transfer within organization.  The benefits are very good.  Name recognition.
cons: Loan processing department not able to handle workload.  Delays on everyones loans resulting in extensions to close at a loss to MLO.

review_title: Fantastic place for a young student
job_title: Part Time Teller in Boston, MA
pros: As a part time student this is a great place for me i have time to balance my studies and my work life and the company works with me if the two ever overlap also they offer up to 5000 per semester in tuition reimbursement. also it will look great on my resume after i graduate
cons: not a place for adults that are no longer in college. a great job for a mature responsible college student

pros: This company offers Diversity and Opportunity across a spectrum of businesses along with Professional Growth. Benefits are fair and competitive. The company also offers flexible work hours and remote login depending on job function
cons: As with any large organization, it is easy to get "lost" in the shuffle. While smaller shops will offer lateral functions, people are usually assigned for specific roles

review_title: It's a big company with a lot of different areas of interest. which will allow you to discover the right overall career
pros: Large company with a types of work that should interest most people, especially as you get deeper and deeper  into the different businesses and units and technologies and you have the opportunistic to look around and decide where I can make my career
cons: Some large strategical projects while good hearteed seem to be dis important due to public outrage, perceived or not, but this has influenced how we react and re react

review_title: Great experience, good opportunity for advancement
job_title: Vice President Sales/Credit in Boston, MA
pros: Great pay, solid training base for all roles, excellent benefits
cons: Many recent layoffs, downsizings, and new Sr level management changes.  Going to take some time to regain steam and momentum.  Has affected the overall culture with so many mergers like ML, Countrywide, et al.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent benefits, great banking center hours, good resources.
cons: Most unprofessional bank. Management was not informative. On my second day, i had to ask an associate what the morning signal was. You'd think thats the first thing they tell you on your first day of work. Due to budget cuts, all training was done online. I spent 5 days reading policies and procedures on the internal website. On my 5th day, I was already told to open new accounts. I did not get to shadow anyone at all.  I previously worked at other financial institutions and i have never experience such terrible training before.

review_title: Love the banking center, HATE corporate.
pros: I have loved working at Bank of America in the banking center.  The people I work with are great and the customers are awesome for the most part.
cons: Peak time is coming up during the summer months and corporate thought it would be a good idea to decrease our banking center staff numbers.  They are decreasing jobs and putting the weight of those lost on the remaining few employees.

pros: Good benefits and pay - never bored - for retail pretty decent hours - opportunity for advancement and changing careers within the company
cons: Some degree of micromanagement - focus tends to be on what is wrong even when the banking center has been very successful - what is success is constantly redefined usually to what you are not doing well in

review_title: Worked with good people but politics get in the way of career advancement within the department.
job_title: Mortgage Servicing Team Manager in Newark, NJ
pros: Many resources, diverse affinity groups, and time off benefits.
cons: Associate dissatisfaction comes from high expectations and not enough time to educate the associates on constant changes in their call flow. Constant changes to associates schedules and limited options if not able to accept the changes. Upper management did not have a good relationship with the site leader which lead to many unresolved frontline management issues.

review_title: Mr. Moynihan seems to be serious about turning things around with most of his initiatives
pros:
Many financial services are available to employees
Flex work program is fantastic and should be celebrated; lately, some Execs are trying to eliminate it
cons:
The bank is perceived poorly due to the bad decisions of a few people over the last 10 years
Compensation across workgroups, for the same or similar jobs, is not consistent
Benefits get worse and more expensive every year - this is a serious issue

review_title: Not healthy in terms of growth, salary, learning, opportunities based on the way company is progressing
pros: Good to start career in bpo industry. Suitable only for correspondence fresh graduates
cons: They have just deteriorted d quality of hiring, hygiene, transport, food and other facilities provided to the employee. Bonus, boa rewards, yearly appraisal is minimal just for d sake of doing it. Immature management and not even appropriately qualified. Moreover copy paste work, no learning and growth opportunities has almost vanished. No new business to generate revenue, company just focussing on cost cutting to maintain profits.

review_title: Decent enough place to work in a small town with few options
pros: Good benefits, paid vacation, sick time, child care.  I love that working in a small town, I really get to know my customers.
cons: No pay for performance for many positions; No follow thru on performance assessments to help build more well-rounded associates.

review_title: Great flexibility, always have feeling of change, and not always for the better.
pros: Flexible work arrangement, can work from home when needed.  Enjoy the people I work with, can have exposure to senior mgmt.  Pay and benefits are hard to beat!
cons: Constant change, to the point of never feeling settled in what you are doing.  Always a feeling of change for the worse, rumors, hard to get the truth about what is going on.  Always feel rushed and asked for changes at 5:30pm for the next morning.  Never have a routine.

review_title: Firm Culture, Diversity, and Career Mobility Review
pros: Great foundation to starting a career, decent benefits, ample system tools to perform tasks if you know what you are looking for.
cons: Office culture is not diverse in finance. BofA culture is dominate and Merrill Lynch only exist for wealth managers who refuse to call themselves BofA-ers. Career Mobility is not transparent across divisions. ERGs are non-functional except for the Women's group. Select group of managers on the rise are incompetent and are  only moving up due to special transformation projects or bumping elbows with the right group.

pros:
Nice selection of technologies
Very smart people - these folks know their stuff from a technological point of view
Decent amount of development work
Several of the developers I'd consider friends
Pay is good
cons:
Very long hours, nights and weekends.
Each release was a catastrophe - every single week.
Clique-ish - if you weren't in the in crowd you got the shaft and eventually let go. Didn't matter how your performance was.

review_title: Great Benefits but Not Very Motivating
pros: Big company with great benefits. Many (not all) managers encourages work/life balance. Co-workers and peers are very professional and easy to work with.
cons: It's just not that motivating. Attempts to make employees feel as though they are actually valued and important part of the organization fall short when employees are being let go and then replaced by contractors, who often are former employees and return contractors.

review_title: Great bank to start with to gain banking experience
pros: You get discounts on products and services. Training took less than 2 weeks on the computer but wasn't very helpful until I got on the teller line to get hands-on experience. Many opportunities to advance into other positions. I personally think that Bank of America is one of the better banks to start your banking experience with because it has an easier entry program and it treats staffs fairly well.
cons: Manager micromanages and it makes me feel uncomfortable sometimes. Low starting wage.

review_title: Constant stress and pressure to make sales.
pros: The employee benefits are some of the best offered, and is the biggest reason that they are able to attract and retain employees.
cons: The lack of proper training for new personnel, and the inability to provide weekly work schedules in advance for those associates who work a fluctuating schedule.

pros: The pay is average for the industry and the discounts are nice. The branch employees are nice.
cons: The training and software are in serious need of an update. Constant turnover, I had 6 managers in 7 months and worked in 3 locations. Management feels it's ok to make customers wait 15 min. so there are lots of angry customers, while branches run with one teller.There was an overall lack of concern for customers just wanted their money and charge them fees. Very greedy company

pros: Great training , benefits, team atmosphere
cons:
low incentives for role expectations and achieving sales goals
performance does not guarantee your career development

job_title: Fraud Analyst in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The company had the right idea on how to work with there employees.
cons: I was a temp and I expressed my passion to be with the company longterm. Once I did that my manager would call my agency about everything I was doing wrong "while still in training". I turned everything around, had the best numbers on my team and then I was let go for coming back from lunch late a couple of minutes.

review_title: Not to bad of an experience
pros: got my foot in the door for some banking experience. the people i worked with were fun, energetic, and the great thing was everyone held their own. they did the work that needed to be done however everyone still had such a charismatic personality which made working there a blast
cons: wished pay was a little more, but hey i had no experience so what are you going to do. sometimes when your having a bad day, the worst of the customers come out in huge hordes.

pros:
Bank of America is a good company to work for if you are in school and you need a part time job.
They have a tuition reimbursement program and offer good health benefits.
My managers were flexible with my quarterly changing school schedules - which i really appreciated.
cons: The pay is not enough for the work you do and sometimes I couldn't get my breaks or lunch because we were short staffed (btw we were always short staffed).

pros: Not a bad place to be nowadays given that two I Banks (Lehman and Bears)  have closed their doors.  Working there was less stressful than either Goldman or Morgan Stanley.
cons: Merrill was a great place to work until it was bought out by BofA.  Merrill was a retail broker and investment bank; BofA is none of the things.  Big culture class was inevitable.

pros: Flexible work schedule if your going to school full time and also decent pay based on early entry positions in other industries.
cons: Working at a call center is not suited for everyone because it requires active multi-tasking and professionalism. You must also be an expert on the product and services you are offering.

review_title: The company is changing...for the worse
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Austin, TX
pros: Competitive compensation compared to similar roles with other companies.
cons: Base salary, company wide, hasn't changed since 2011 when the role was first created. Limited career growth considering the role doesn't allow you to own/manage a specific book of clients.

review_title: Great benefits but lots of pressure to overachieve
pros: Health insurance is great, time off is decent
cons: Lots of sales pressure makes you feel like you cannot help clients, just need to push products/sales. Compensation not equal among those with similar experience/performance. 100% isn't enough, 150% is ok, 200% is best

pros: Decent base salary that doesn't go away, depending on your banking center location you can have good leads walking in the door.
cons: Ridiculous micro management, they force you to make calls on a recorded line even to existing clients where you have to treat them like you don't know them and verify them before you can discuss anything. Compensation plan has changed multiple times and has always made it harder to make more money. They only have one managed investment offering, which has performed poorly, yet they basically force you to sell it (or annuities) otherwise you can't hit your goals.

review_title: Terrible company if you work in loan servicing. Managers and HR do not care about the employees.
pros: Benefits are decent...that's about it. Not a lot of pros when you work for the devil. Good luck is all I can say.
cons: No communication amongst management and departments. Employees are treated poorly. Training is almost nonexistent. Managers are overworked. HR and Sr Management spew nothing but lies. Everyone is disposable and just a number. Systems are inefficient, outdated and broken. Massive layoffs have reduced the workforce to uneducated, unmotivated and uncaring employees. Morale is horrible! This is by far, the worst company.

pros: Great benefits. 12 weeks paternal leave, male or female. Paid.
cons:
Absolutely no purpose to have an assistant manager and a branch manager at this bank,
Branch manager literally expected to stand in lobby with an ipad to direct customer traffic to bankers who don't even report to Branch Manager (they report to sattellite regional manager).

I do not see the bank keeping this structure for long. Felt like a dispensible position.

The bank also force transferrs employes (especially leaders) like they are furniture, not human beings. No relationships with customers or staff which creates a lot of distrust.

pros: Potential to earn commission, pays up to $5200 for training, they say there are career paths.....hours are pretty good, no overtime
cons: HR was a joke to deal with, training managers are clueless, inconsistencies in starting pay, prepared to be pissed off when you find out the idiot sitting next to you got a better offer for 'undisclosed reasons'

pros: Better work life balance than most companies.  Well defined procedures implemented in technology.  Good benefits and surrounded by good people
cons: Management views people as expenses to be cut rather than assets.  Constant six sigma style layoffs make you loose loyalty to a company that clearly has no loyalty to you.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Specialist II in Glen Allen, VA
pros: They offered flexible hours, good pay, good training was provided and maintained, and they occasionally had fun team building exercises.
cons: Management was out of touch with reality. "Teams" were always being shifted around and split up under new managers. Sales practices were  shady, often manipulating people into doing something they didn't really want so you could meet your quota. Sales goals were unrealistic.

pros: If you want to start out in the retail banking industry and learn the foundation of consumer banking services, then Bank of America is a great company to work for.
cons: Operational hiccups would cost the team as a whole a margin of their bonuses at the failure of one incompetent coworker. Sales is a field where your individual performance should outweigh a team problem (especially when it's specifically a compliance issue).

pros: Bank of America is a great company to work for. I have been here for just under 10 years. They see skills that are useful in other areas and set you up for success. The benefits are also very good.
cons: Too Many layoffs, manger changes, job title changes without compensation, location changes all within the same job code. Lots of uncertainty in the past few years.

pros:
Great benefits
Decent 401k investment options
3 weeks vacation a year
2 weeks sick time
Bonus potential is a nice incentive
cons:
Old systems (NEED TO UPDATE)
Call volumes can be stressful, we need more support in this department.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Po Kong, Kowloon City
pros: Great benefits, Great community. They encourage a balance work and personal life. lost a programs to volunteer and be part of.
cons:
*Pay is less than industry average I feel. Difficult to get a good raise or to move up with in the company. They pay outsiders more, than internal applicants.
* Simple processes are very complex, lots or red tape. they make something so simple very complex, resulting in unnecessary stress. Need to use lots of system, compared to competitors. They need to stream line processes and upgrade systems.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Orlando, FL
pros: Professional and personal development in finance and banking.
cons:
-For a company of its size, it is horribly disorganized. 
-Management does not take ownership of problems. It is a finger pointing environment or an ignore the problems mentality. 
-Goals are unrealistic and causes significant frustration for field teams.

review_title: Very good experience! This is my first time in the financial industry and I am learning a lot!
pros: Great team, integrity, awesome schedule with even greater benefits! I always have a leader or peer to lean on and everyone wants to see you learn and grow in your role
cons: Sometimes you have to work 2-3 Saturday’s in a row but vacation/personal time help out. Make sure not to involve yourself in other peoples drama, don’t air your dirty laundry at work

review_title: Very good job for someone in college or fresh out of school
pros:
You can work your way up in the company with the right mentors.
The health insurance is good.
Starting wage in NY metropolitan area is $15/hr.
No uniform, just have to dress appropriately.
cons:
Breaks are too short (30 minutes) and may be interrupted to help with customers.
On your feet all the time.
Customers will drive you insane if you don't have the strength.
Since I am part time, I am the last one to choose my vacation days, I never get Saturdays off even if I request it.

pros: Lots of opportunity to move around to different roles. Many good people who will challenge you and push you. Reasonable compensation. Great focus on community work.
cons: Overly focused on short term. Changing management often means changing priorities...and that happens a lot. Tendency to get a good idea up to the starting line and then pull or reduce funding to meet a short term need. Could do much more to strengthen the front line especially with compensation, but the majority of that money goes to people who never see a customer.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY
pros: Their benefits are great and provide you with a good amount of vacation time
cons: Don't believe them during the interview process in regards to quarterly bonuses.  Don't expect to get paid what they tell you until you see it on your paystub.  I was a Financial Center Manager and there is zero market level support. Tons of turnover at every level including District/Market Level.  They pay more than other banks, but it is a toxic environment.  Huge pay gaps for people at the same level with the same level of experiences ( no equal pay). Systems and back office support is lacking an effects customer service.

pros: good place to work for great benfits
cons: Was with company for 3 years and it was impossible to get the days i need off

review_title: Good  Organization to work in with some cons
pros: Brand  Value Long history Work Culture working ethics are good. Pay scale and perks are at part with other public sector  banks.
cons: Work life balance growth opportunities  pay is not at par if compared to development  banks. Working  hours are 10 12 hours at most urban centers.

pros: Great benefits. Room for growth in the financial center.

pros:
1. In few projects , work-life balance is good

2. Just like other product based companies and banks , there is no variable pay

7. Food is worst

review_title: Most of the people are nice
pros: CO-workers are friendly, culture is odd blend of friendly and back stabbing
cons: Processes poorly documented, too many kingdoms, continuous shuffle of team-mates and groups. Lots of lip service but little real progress.

review_title: Work there for a short period of time and then leave ASAP.
job_title: Supply Chain Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Provides an opportunity to learn the banking industry and new banking products.
cons:
Highly policitical organization.  In order to advance, you have to "be in" with the right people.  Management is only interested in making themselves wealthier.  They is no interest in advancing the front line workers.  Management plays games with information and employees are always jockeying for position so as not to be laid-off in the next round of cuts (there seem to be layoffs EVERY year).  
Negotiate a high salary coming in because pay increases are stingy.

pros: great hours, vaction pay, sick time, tuition program, associate discount program, people are great to work with, flexable schedule, constant change.
cons: high pressure sales, lots of conference calls, refferal goals, action plans, saturday hours being open untill 2 on saturdays, moving up is hard to do because of HR.

pros: It's a great place to work if you don't have any career ambitions. Environment is very laid back, lots of freedom, management is quite flexible. Nobody cares what you do as long as your job is done.
cons: Very depressing environment as everyone is absolutely indifferent to their jobs, colleagues, and company they work for. Very hard to stay motivated.

pros: There was the opportunity to work on a reasonable amount of deal flow to build experience and put on the resume.
cons: I went to BofA as an MBA associate, and took the risk of choosing them over some other good offers.  My mistake.  They fired 7 out of 8 associates in my group and out of my MBA associate class of 80 some odd people maybe 6 are left today.  BTW - I worked until 2am the night before I was laid off.  Thanks for the memories.

review_title: The glamor is in the Finance, not very suitable if you are looking to improve Tech skills.
pros: Nice place to work for techies who are interested in Finance and want to grow / shape their career in the Finance domain.
cons: Not a good place if you are looking for cutting edge technology, improving your tech skills, having an awesome set of co-developers.

pros: Great Benefits, good discounts, generous vacation and sick days; hours are decent
cons: Compensation is way below par; senior management is incompetent and out of touch with reality. Policies and procedures are exhaustive; minimal room for advancement; technology is antiquated - some depts still have DOS based systems that they decided to keep when they acquired from Countrywide.

review_title: The job itself sometimes is very disatisfying but at times can be ok
pros: They have the best benefits and the pay is somewhat decent compared to other companies.
cons: Very dissatisfied with the opportunities on moving up.  When you work data entry, you pretty much are a nobody or at least you feel that way.

review_title: Glad to be here, but would rather be somewhere else.
job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Pennington, AL
pros: There is a very good work/life balance. I have the abilitly to leave my job at the office and go home and forget about it, which allows me to relax more.
cons: Sometimes feel like you are trapped in your position. Times are tough right now and some would say they are lucky to have a job at all, but there should be more room for advancement. I am the highest rated member on my team too... Also, in my specific area, pay is very low.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: Great time off, family and work life balance, great program to work from home.
cons:
Senior managers do the least to get by and then wonder why the Bank gets in trouble for how it services mortgages.  It is hard to institute change at the bank.
