cons: Horrible. Sales is all that matters. You have 7 managers emailing you every 10 minutes to do better. Its a lazy job, sit down all day. Its customer servive so your are a punching bag all day from clients. Some managers are helpful, others ignore if you message them for help. Its also a negative place to work. Everyone wants to leave, high turn over. Very hard to move up in the company.

review_title: BOA is place of learning and staying relevant.
pros:
There are many pros to be working at an organizationthat respects every employee equally and includes all aspects of an employee's life,from getting trained on their various educational portals to family days and inter cricket tournaments specifically for the ladies,which is laudable.
The work is systematized and top quality as far as a client of the bank is considered.
BOA is a place to learn and deliver,but with inclusiveness.
cons: The transport facility is one area I would like to see improvement.

review_title: Bank of America is a great company to work for as far as benefits go. its like "ground hogs day" but is worth it.
pros: Great educational benefits. Ideal job for those who want to go to college, Because Bank will repay you for some/most of your tuition, and its more than $2000 a calender yr.
cons: You are going to Work your butt off...PERIOD ! but if you do whats expected, then you will be rewarded most times.

review_title: No bullsh*t , The truth about BOA.
job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Miami, FL
pros: Benefits are wonderful. Paid childcare, maternity leave paid for 3 months including dads. 401k plan is matched, 3 wks paid vacation. 10 sick days. Bonus are good as long as you are in hoots with your manager, otherwise they can dock you 50% of it.
cons: Changing policies daily, one way its this, tomorrow is that. When promotions or offers end, they don't advise the staff. Management changes drastically.

job_title: Assistant Banking Center Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: If you work hard and really have a drive to succeed, then you can do it here.
cons: They could do better with allowing associates to balance work and life. Being out of owrk for any reason is a big issue. If you are out then you had better be in the hospital or all hell will break loose and you will never hear the end of it and your commitment will always be questioned.

review_title: Good place to hide if you have no aspirations
job_title: Vice President Consultant Systems Engineering in Concord, CA
pros: The work-life benefits are excellent.  The scale alone is worth doing time here.  Open to moving anywhere in the country and within the company.
cons: Mergers killed any possible options for organic growth.  The culture differences are apparent, both by location and by what company you were merged from.

review_title: Decent company with lot of room for improvement.
pros: Bank of America offers decent pay but good benefits. As one of the the largest bank in the nation, it has a lot of career advancement opportunities.
cons:
It is often difficult to work with other departments in the company. 
Some of its banking policies make it hard for employees to provide good customer services.

job_title: Trust and Fund Services Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Massive network of potential connections within the company. BAC does everything in finance, so if you have the drive and meet the right people, you can probably accomplish your career goals. Benefits are above average and seem to get better every year.
cons: The company culture (in my department at least) leaves a lot to be desired. Most employees seem very bitter/uneasy in their jobs and it rubs off on how employees interact. Metrics to determine advancement are confusing and inconsistent all over the place.

review_title: If you want to make money must be willing to relocate
job_title: Senior Fraud Analyst in College Park, GA
pros: Benefits, respect when you tell people where you work, lots of room for growth must be willing to go where the oppurtunitys are.  Stable, if laid off great severence packages, the associate discounts are amazing since most top companies bank with us.
cons: For my department if I want to move up must be willing to relocate to delaware, phoenix or charlotte.  Because of recession bonuses have been cut, really noticing that on my paycheck.

job_title: Senior Vice President in Boston, MA
pros: The former leadership of Ken Lewis has left the bank with a deep culture of no-nonsense. The bank's operation is the best in the country.
cons:
Unfortunately it got screwed by the acquisitions of Countrywide and Merrill and we as employees and shareholders are still paying the price. When will my 401K composed of BAC stocks come back to 401K from 1K? Hopefully in another 10 years.
Too many reorgnizations and too frequent changes. Low morale because of the acquisitions. Compensation stayed on the same level forever

pros: Because it is a diversified workplace and offers many opportunities for one to explore and reach out that our relevant to anyone's area of interest.
cons: There is not a system that includes all the states.

job_title: Officer; Trust and Funds Services Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent online learning classes available to broaden knowledge and horizons.  Stable employment (you have to really screw something up to be fired, or just utterly incompetent.)
cons: Large bureaucratic 300,000+ corporation = impossible to 'stand out'.  Bonuses/advancements are not in line with work performed, but rather allocated from high up.

review_title: easy but monotonous, and the benefits are great but i can barely take care of myself on the pay.
pros: Benefits, no weekends.  Major holidays off, decent hours yearly bonuses and pay raises.
cons: Little room to grow for low level employees.  Management seems clueless about operations.

pros: Good work life balance.  Management is very supportive of work life balance.  MyWork program offers opportunity to work from home.
cons: Teams are too fragmented with too many different reporting lines which makes it hard to work together.  There is not enough communication on major decisions.  US is still calling the shots but they lack a global understanding of how things work internationally.  Career progression is not good and promotion is not transparent.

review_title: The job experience at BofA depends alot on your direct manager and peers.
pros: They have good benefits including health, gym, and shopping discounts.  There are internal resources for internal education tutorials and I found many co-workers willing to network.
cons: Alot of the decisions affecting job security are made at a high level, so direct managers often do not have input into who is let go.

review_title: Very welcoming and great place to work
pros: The people I work with are very friendly. Excellent training in place to help me succeed. Great opportunities to move up.
cons: Large company which makes it a little harder to get recognized. You will work more hours the higher you get promoted

job_title: PMD Financiual Advisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent training and continuing education on products and services. They are not at all shy about spending money on trainings; the starting pay is higher than any I've seen for an entry level FA position.
cons: Really are thrown to the wolves; not very much time to attain the hurdles which start out as being very attainable but then very quickly become exceedingly difficult. Not a very high percentage will make it past the first year of the program.  Need a much better structured mentoring program

review_title: 9 years of good benefits, good Training, But a lack of pay
pros: Prior to the collapse it was icreadile. Promote within. Good training. Excellent team building events. Tuition reimbursement, Benefits
cons: They treat the position like retail but its not your dealing with peoples money and there is a risk factor everyday you come to work. Your just a number, raises are uncommon. No production=no job.

review_title: All the talk in the news is true,well at least about the default mortgage part of Bank of America. Bad business practice
pros: There might be some pros in other departments and growth once you get out of default mortgage servicing, but as far as this department is doomed.
cons: No ethics in the home mortgage department. Wrongful foreclosures. no one listens to suggestions from front line associates.

review_title: Could have been a lot better
pros: Workable hours, face to face contact with the general public, good health care and other benefits, flexible scheduling according to need.
cons: Very poor communication between management and the general workforce. No flexibility regarding sales duties, all tellers must meet cross sales quotas even if they see the same clients everyday.

review_title: Good opportunities, great culture & support for education
pros: I rotated through a couple of banks and found that experiences vary considerably by location, but for the most part people had upbeat attitudes and valued hard workers. My managers were extremely flexible working hours around changing class schedules.
cons: Stingy with teller hourly wages. Too much emphasis on bubbly, inauthentic personalities. Training on more advanced systems and functions was pretty difficult to come by.

review_title: You get back what you put in
job_title: Banking Center Assistant Manager in New York, NY
pros: If you are good at what you do, they do give great recognition. Upon exceeding my goals I was offered a Management position without even applying.
cons: It's important to be open for change, and to really like people. Policies and goals can change in an instant and you work with people with very different personalities. This can be a major pro for some people and a con for others who are not as socially inclined or likes constant consistency.

job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Phoenix, AZ
pros: They tend to pay a higher than industry average wage for the branch associates.
cons: This place is ultra sensitive when it comes to any negative comments by customers or negative press. They are in the middle of serious cut backs as the current CEO is trying to undo the damage from the previous CEO. The staff who have been in the branch the longest are slow to embrace the change and tend to look at outsiders with a negative eye.

review_title: Ok company, not so great management
pros: Good benefits, multiple locations all over on case once decide to try a different state, job will follow
cons: Does not pay well and there is favoritism from management to certain groups of employees. Inequality

job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Working at such a large institution offers opportunities to be involved in many different areas, the culture embraces flexibility such as working from home But demands results.
cons: Cost pressures mean pay increases are minimal and the amount of work expected is well above Average - although the flexibility means that work can often be done at a time and location of your choosing ( instead of working late at the office sign on after the kids have gone to bed and finish things up thaT night at home)

review_title: Full of people who work hard and honestly try to do the right thing while balancing policies and satisfaction.
pros: Excellent coworkers, direct management easy to get along with, frequent recognition, good pay, excellent benefits.
cons: Overwhelming (and sometimes conflicting) policies, corporate management secrecy, frequently-shifting business focus.

pros: I joined the company as a fresher and worked there for 5 yrs got lot of things to learn. We have a good opportunity to learn new things, good work culture, i felt as home like environment. Good management. We will  know the growth structure very well  u will not have any confusion abt it.
cons: I felt that only negative is the transport system now a day's. It was also good in the initial stage but now the bus system is not upto the mark.

review_title: Big bank's are very similar and job function and culture really depend upon your immediate organization.
pros: Great benefits, vacation, maternity-paternity leave.
cons: Lay-offs seem to occur yearly or every other year failry frequest and if you have never experienced one it is rare. Executive leadership can change drastically and rotates every few years as to how the management style and goals affect the trickle down approach.

review_title: Only people with no drive should work here
pros: I would only suggest people right out of school to work here. If you have any creativity or drive you will get frustrated with working at this company. This company doesn't feel the need to have people that want to think outside the box.
cons: No salary increases, however they have no problem raising the cost of your benefits year after year.

pros:
Best learning environment. After you've trained here and conquered your position any other teller position will be a piece of cake.
Personal growth. If you spend 40 hours a week with the same faces, you bought make some friends in the process.
Professional growth. Career advancement fast if you show you're worth it.
Benefits. Medical, vision, school tuition.
cons:
Multi tasking is the word.
Running financial transaction while talking to customer trying to sell products while at the same time keeping the line moving fast and maintaining the office running smoothly.

pros: Great benefits and pay is competitive. That's about it the rest is all production oriented and focus is on widget sales instead of long term relationships
cons: Work life balance is out of whack with Saturday banking requiring 4-5 on and 1 off usually. You hardly ever have 2 days off together to recharge. Difficult to navigate service areas when you're trying to help a customer. Corporate strategy doesn't translate down to branches as all local management cares about is the sales interaction vs doing the right thing for customer in long run

review_title: There was no home life/work life balance. Because of the business falling, each day always felt like your last.
pros: The office culture felt like a family oriented environment. As a trainer, I was often given leverage over training decisions for our department.
cons: You do not have a voice. There is often a request for open and honest feedback, but anything "honest" is not very welcomed.

job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Bank of America is a very large company. Provides a lot of scope to move horizontally in the bank. The IB division is very vibrant and hectic. Several opportunities as bank mvoes to use new platform. Good work life balance. You can have several opportunities to grow within the bank. Based on your manager's discretion, you have flexibility to work from different work locations.
cons: Very hectic. Benefits are pretty poor. especially medical benefits. At times dysfucntional management which changes strategies so very often.

pros: Wonderful benefits, decent pay, great hours, lots of managerial support for success. It's a great opportunity to learn about how the finance industry works if you take the job seriously.
cons: Limited opportunities for growth, lengthy track for advancement when starting at the bottom, beware of some micromanagement from mid level bosses. If you do a great job you will probably get moved around the market with the same pay scale. Products sold are not as beneficial as they were a couple of years ago. There are constant personnel changes.

pros: Worked there for 7 years in the mortgage division. Awesome benefits, growth potential, plenty of on the job and materials testing and training.
cons: Very poor management. Since the company is a huge corporation the communication and customer service  for both employees and the customers is terrible. Work flow that is implemented by upper management simply is inefficient. Outsourcing is also a huge problem.

review_title: Decent experience, however company does not value quality employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Policies to manage to
My direct manager was great
Tools and resources needed to do my job were always available
cons:
Decisions made at the very top were not based on employee value or quality work
Some employees who were just place-holders continued in leadership roles which caused poor decision-making and low morale for their employees.

pros: Decent pay, comfortable work environment, easy to advance in company. Sales pressure is not too high. Fun employee incentives. In my last branch I even had my own office and bathroom!
cons: The worst part is that there are no bonuses for opening accounts and building relationships. All the money goes to management and higher while sales and tellers work super hard to meet goals.

pros: I was attending college and working at BoA part-time and they were very understanding about my school schedule. Management worked to get me the right schedule and provided good hours for me to work. Also, the benefits and pay is better than most places.
cons: Like any other customer service job, you encounter unpleasant customers every now and then; people tend to get angry quick in regards to their money. Also, my location was very busy most of the time and closing the bank took longer than anyone would have wanted it to.

job_title: Assistant Vice President Call Center Supervisor in Miami, FL
pros: Working environment was that of family. You work hard you get rewarded accordingly.  Don't go into a role expecting easy street.  But again, you will be rewarded heavily if one of their top producers
cons: Hours are 7 days a week. Shift can vary. Workload is HUGE! Sales pressure is there. The bar WILL be raised every time you meet or exceed goal.

pros:
Results Driven
Care for employees
Committed to helping someone with their career aspirations 
Get to work with some very smart people
Great Work/Life balance
cons:
The company is so big that it takes forever to get anything approved
Incredibly bureaucratic
Constantly moving divisions within the firm 
Culture is a little outdated

review_title: Good place to work, for some
pros: Community Service opportunities and volunteer events, Decent compensation, Technology is pretty good
cons: Bonus, travel and morale budgets seem non-existent, Massive downscaling of MyWork flexible program may cause very valuable, talented and experienced employees to bolt to competitors, Benefits are costly, Large-scale re-organizations every year doesn't promote stability and productivity

pros: They are always looking to keep you in the company and the benefits are great as well. They offer tuition assistance, discounts, and some free accounts. They truly care about your membership with the company.
cons: It is kind of hard to move up the latter. Everything seems to be based off of the amount of years you've been there and not really your skill or expertise.

pros: Benefits, time off & my team leaders were all great!  They have an open door policy & I could walk into my team leader or managers office & talk with them. The company stands by their values. They also support volunteering in the community.
cons: Since the company is so large, it's difficult to find contacts in other departments. They lost a lot of good employees due to overall staff reductions.

review_title: Decent company, lots of areas to move between
job_title: Senior Pricing Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great benefits, if you like to move around different businesses / focuses you have this opportunity.  Lots of volunteering opportunities.
cons: Work life balance is poor.  Bonuses are much lower than industry average for non-executive managers.  The company is flattening out organizations and shrinking (letting people leave and not backfilling) so less chance of moving up or gaining management experience.

review_title: Good, but can be better and more technologically based.
pros: The pay is better than other banks. I am lucky to have a good team. Management is supportive, helpful, and I learn a lot from them.
cons: My center is old. There's no pictures or music in the center. The systems and the processing are old and should be updated.

pros:
Good vertical development opportunities and internal training
Internal hiring and management will help you succeed if you want to
Amazing benefits package
A good 9 to 5 job. All overtime is reimbursed and so it is not encouraged.
cons:
Long hours of angry customers coming to you with problems you can't solve
High turnover of employees esp management makes decision making confusing 
Communication is sometimes roundabout thereby conflicting

job_title: Post-Foreclosure Specialist II in Chandler, AZ
pros: Larger corporate structure means you can keep your head down and treat it like just a job. Also potential to move up if you want to do that. Decent benefits.
cons: You can easily get lost in "corporate America". Pretty much a cube farm. Everything had guidelines and processes and it felt very bureaucratic. If you like to fit square pegs in square holes, this is the place for you. If you are an independent free-thinker who likes challenges and using your full potential, I'd suggest looking elsewhere.

pros:
You get paid
You get insurance
cons:
Massive bureaucracy in which half of management is in denial that there's a chargeback for IT services and the other half of management enforces it.  Result?  Workers are begging for "free" services when these fees should just be budgeted.

Educational reimbursement?  No.  Only if you want to start over completely with the one approved degree program.

Paid training or conferences?  Forget it, not going to happen.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros:
Very easy to move around in the company if you're a hard worker
Laid back environment
Great amount of vacation time for a US company
Many departments, so easy to find a niche where you want to go
cons:
Management is not very transparent about large changes in the business
Some departments are laid off with little to no warning
Many employees leave to pursue employment at other banks for higher pay

pros: great health benefits, nice coworkers, good manager
cons: We were short-handed all the time. When I joined the bank, there were 3 tellers;then only 1.5 tellers, now there is only 1 teller left the bank. It is hard to manage clients during lunch time. Also, since Toss and Operation Managers are eliminated in the market. There is not too much move upward opportunities for tellers who are good at operation. Moreover, IT support is very limited and the technology is old.

pros: Good benefits.  Good training.  Large footprint so you can move with the job if you want.  We are serious about growth while being ethical about it.
cons: Never enough staff. Expectations are set as if you have all the time in the world.  One person calling in sick can kill all your plans for the day.

review_title: This company offers a great work-life balance.
job_title: Mortgage Underwriter in Fort Worth, TX
pros: This company offers an overall good benefits package which includes but not limited to: option to purchase an additional week of vacation, 6% 401k match, and bank holidays.
cons: This company could improve on streamlining procedures and processes regarding communication within the same line of business. The lack of streamlined communication appears complicated to the consumer which will result in a loss of customer retention.

review_title: Was great, but not as much as it used to be
job_title: Senior Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Strong benefits , though health care has gotten expensive.  Good level of opportunity in some areas.
cons: Not as much focus on employee satisfaction as in prior years.  Flexibility has dropped significantly since telework program was black listed.  Now you have to do some major jumping through hoops to even be considered, and even then are still in jeopardy of getting it taken away.

job_title: Banking Center Manager in Jensen Beach, FL
pros: Benefits, competitive pay, learning position, great coworkers, room for advancement, huge global company, great hours. Really a great environment. Local management was very engaged.
cons: Fairly high pressure environment. There is a lack of focus on serving the customer, and a heavy focus on gaining the customer's full portfolio. Which is fine, but there is definitely a distaste built in to the job for good old help and customer service.

pros: Great Benefits, 4 weeks vacation, great work life balance
cons: Every increasing sales goals, more of a banking sales role than a financial advisor, you do not have a book of business of your own, high turnover in the role, highly micro managed

review_title: Cash department- hard work, fast pace, flexible, team family.
pros: Better benefits than most companies. Flexible in done departments. Cafeteria on site. Promote networking within the company. 4 months maternity leave for mother/father.
cons: Not paid what other employers are paying their employees. The company puts more in to their benefits then salaries. Focus in on quantity not quality

pros: offer a great benefits package include health, dental, & eye insurance. full 401k & it begins as soon as you're hired so no probationary period
cons: greatly underpaid, dont care about employees or making someone commute an hour + ONE WAY, training is basic, 30 min lunch break, constant policy changes that negatively effect customers so employees ALWAYS getting yelled and cursed at. horrible culture, does not promote growth & will pass a promotion to someone who doesn't have experience just so they will not have to pay your desired salary. HORRIBLE PLACE TO WORK, PERIOD.

pros:
Leading benefits.
You can become fairly independent and routine.
Can nudge yourself into less stressful roles.
Good for middle manager type positions.
cons:
Stagnant in terms of roles, salaries and bonuses. 
No place to go once you reach middle management unless you are in HQ.
Leadership out of touch with field realities.
Messaging that ranges from cheesy to hypocrisy. 
Lot of churn in management.

job_title: Commercial Associate in New York, NY
pros: Good work-life balance. Great for those who love to chill and read barstool/troll tinder (seriously, it's not a very demanding job).
cons: Not great pay. Only real path for most people in this position is to be a "relationship manager", which is basically a salesperson tasked with selling mainly (but not exclusively) treasury products. The bank will pitch this as a role where you can go anywhere and do anything within the bank. The truth is, again, for most in this role, relationship manager is as good as it gets.

pros: Definitely solid training, and referrals from bankers. Pay scale and spiffs.
cons: The support could be better, as well as loan requirements. A lot of waiting till the loan is halfway processed to alter requirements and need for more from client causing lots of delays and sometimes denials for overqualified clients. Also the fact that only the upper  echelon of clients are able to be qualified is difficult to deal with and limits your business.

review_title: Decent base pay and benefits. Terrible work environment and terrible investments you need to sell
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Richmond, VA
pros: Great benefits. Base salary of 60k+ is competitive as an FA base.
cons:
The compensation plan is meant for you to only get credit for about 80% of what you do. I missed out on about 2-4 thousand quarterly due to loopholes in comp system. 

They also micromanage everything from outbound e-mails to outbound calls. All must be recorded.

review_title: Inadequate management is the only bad quality
pros: Fantastic work life balance. Easy job. Decent pay but could be better.
cons: Horrid, adolescent managers. I'm former active duty military, I know what a good leader entails. These guys have no accountability for themselves or their subpar employees. Nor do they have a care in the world as long as they look good. Quite sad, as I'd make this a lasting career if it weren't for them.

job_title: Senior Client Service Representative in Utica, NY
pros: Great advancement opportunities, plenty of paid time off for sick and vacation. The work environment is friendly. Calls are fast paced making your day fly by. Paid training. Very flexible if you need to change a day on your schedule. Good coaching
cons: There is a possibility of having a shift optimization (1ce every couple years) meaning your schedule can change and you have to bid on which shift you want based off how well you perform. And which shifts the bank needs more people working. And policies change regularly.

review_title: B of A is the worst place on earth to work
job_title: VP Marketing Info Manager II  in Bangalore
pros: They're always hiring...even in bad economy.
cons: I was the victim of one of the worst cases of workplace mobbing that place has ever seen.   Management just turns a blind eye to situations where unscrupulous managers wreak havoc on their innocent subordinates, often costing them their jobs, and the upper management just looks the other way while they know it's going on.

pros: The people I work with are great, but moral is really dropping to an all time low.
cons: Management like to spit out positive phrases and comments, with no intentions of honoring it.  Example:  there are plenty of opportunities within the BANK.  When there's a job opening within the BANK, they deny you from applying.

review_title: Contract Mortgage Closer - $17.00/hr - No benefits as a contractor.
pros: People seem helpful, most seem to have a good work ethic.  Management tries to provide small perks to employees for hitting monthly goals.
cons: Hours can be very long at month end... however that is expected in this postion.  The job can also be very stressful and is very fast-paced.

review_title: Research playing field before accepting offer.
pros: Good health benefits offered to its employees.
cons: Pay is not all that great.  Would highly recommend checking out other mortgage companies for loan servicing  before considering Bank of America.

review_title: Great Company to get your start with
pros:
Fantastic Benefits
Great Co-Workers
Bank of Opportunity
Fast promotions
You are encouraged for a job well done
Transparent Management team
cons: There is ONLY ONE downside of working for Bank of America. THEY DO NOT PAY! I received a 16 Thousdand dollar increase by leaving Bank of America to go to a rival Bank.

pros: I moved to an AVP role within 3 years with no prior banking experience.  Was able to show I was a top performer and stand out from the bunch.
cons: Opportunity is available but it ususally dwendells down to who you know.  Recession is probably a set back while other advancing roles are not plentiful as they were a few years ago.

review_title: It's a melting pot to meet all different kinds of people.
pros: The atmosphere and people are what I enjoyed most while working here. My tasks were relevant and allowed me to tailor how to execute my tasks in a new and more efficient manner.
cons: It's not the easiest place to move up on the corporate ladder. Many people have been in the same department for many years without a lot a opportunity to grow.

pros: Excellent total reward package.  The supported me when I wanted to do voluntary work, and allowed me time off to do so.
cons: Overall my experiences working at Bank of America were positive and I enjoyed my job.  I worked with some fantastic colleagues who helped and mentored me througout my career there.

review_title: Bank of America, is one of the best places to work.
pros:
Career Advancement
Great Pay
Great Benefits
Excellent customer base and customer service
cons: From my aspect there are no down sides of working at Bank of America.

pros: The benefits at Bank of America are outstanding.  My immediate supervisor's were supportive, listened to ideas and promoted an inclusive work environment.
cons: On the job training is the norm in many areas, creates inconsistent processes.  Recognition is lacking in some areas.  Change to improve workflow is slow to be implemented.

review_title: Ok benefiitsbut definitely not the best bank to work for
pros:
Great co-workers
Free checking and saving interest bearing accounts
Employee credit cards at low fixed rates
cons:
Commission structure is awful and forever changing
Commission structure is handicapped against top performers(the more you sell the higher the bar is set)
Overall commission monthly has decreased in the last year (from 1200 a month to 300 a month for top performers)
Advancement opportunities are few and fair between for top performers

job_title: Sales and Service Specialist in Kingston, NY
pros: Gain vital experience in sales. Good training that is actually taken seriously. Upper management seems to have a plan for each associates career based on their skills and career goals. The company is working very hard to improve reputation damage received during financial crisis and former leadership.
cons: Ability to solve problems for some products from the banking center can be limited. Bad press constantly plagues us. Moving across channels can be difficult...ie: from retail baking to wealth management.

job_title: Vice President in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Solid benefits, talented team members, experienced senior managers
cons: The bank is slowly reducing the quality of benefits whether it be retirement or health insurance benefits.  They are better than industry standards but it would be nice for the bank to be a leader in benefits rather than trying to fit in with the pack.

job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I cannot speak on behalf of all departments within the organization.  However, in my department, my Manager was very supportive of what I wanted to do with my career.  My fellow Associates and I were also supportive of one another as well.
cons: You do work with some fellow Associates who were loyal to the previous bank after a merger. Thus, making it difficult to work in the department.  I either avoid them or wait until they eventually change their feelings towards the new bank.

pros: benefits are excellent..  Great Hours. Great pay for every position.
cons: they don't care about associates, all they care about is SALES. there is not teamwork because of the pressure you have to meet your goals. Management is horrible. lots of observations every week even if you are exceeding in your goals, they will always find something to tell you even if it does not make any sense.

review_title: Was a great learning experience despite people being bitter and management not caring about internal promoting.
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Pays well, learn a lot on the job in a fast environment, has a great reputation for future employment.
cons: 80+ hour work weeks consistently, hard to make vacation or weekend plans and management treats people differently (in a bad way) when they know people will be moving on at the end of their analyst program. Helping young people feel appreciated would go a long way in improving their quality of life and happiness with the job.

pros: Very easy phone and face to face interview and very quick. Job was easy.
cons: Training was terrible and professionalism at the branch non existent. pros: Great Benefits. Great hours. Helpful tuition and daycare reimbursement
cons:
must make 100% of goal to get commission. Commission is quarterly, so you have to wait to get the extra check. 
Cutting on FTE and we are continued being told that we are over on hours. Employees are taken advantage of. 
Very controlling on how our conversations with customers need to sound like. I am always a top performer and my customers love me. That shouldn't matter.

review_title: If You Want to Have A Stroke Apply Here.
pros: Benefits: Health, vacation, sick time are excellent!
cons: They overwork their staff, and they micro manage. Bank of America does not trust their employees. After all the background, credit checks, and fingerprints they will stand behind you and go over ever little detail. Seriously everyone checks behind your work, and it makes you wonder why they employ people if they watch and review everything you do.

review_title: Comfortable environment, some pros and cons.
pros:
Work life balance emphasis - but you have to work at it.  There's a flex work culture.
Environment can set you up to grow your skill level quite a lot, but you also have to make sure to fight for the projects that will let you do that, get the right managers and support, etc.
cons: A lot of emphasis on risk and process can boggle down the work. Lots of things get cancelled too often (mostly the "cool" projects), which can be a downer.

pros: Good benefits.  I was treated like a professional and was empowered to a degree I had not been before.  Large program for employees to work from home.  Compensation was competitive.  Management at all levels does a pretty good job of communicating with employees.  Did a pretty good job of providing training as needed, and online courses on many topics were plentiful.
cons: Difficulties (especially financial) due to prior mergers creates an uneasiness as the company tries to steady itself.  Very large company.

review_title: Good company to work for depending on the division you work in.
pros: Certain positions are available to work remotely which offsets the long hours.  Company is very oriented to giving back to the community.
cons: IT area I work in is high pressure due to very aggressive timelines.  Virtually no funding for training outside of some internal resources.  Due to economic conditions, currently very flat on financial salary increases and higher cost to benefits.

review_title: Best job I have ever had
pros: This company has amazing benefits!
cons: You must stay in a position for a year before you can advance to another one. And retail banking side seems very female dominated.

review_title: 10 year career coming to an end
job_title: Operations Project Consultant in Plano, TX
pros:
Flexible work schedules and pay but happiness does hinge on who you work for.
People are great to work with and open to constructive criticism.
cons:
Mortgage industry has taken a beating and B of A has been the poster child. Benefits are a bit high considering the size of the company and who knows what impact obamacare will have long term.
Technology infrastructure is convoluted.

job_title: Clerical Assistant in East Point, GA
pros: I have much to offer in the way of diversity of experience and profession, because I have worked in various major industries. Within these industries I have had the opportunity to learn human resource policies, procedures and the protocol necessary to enforce them ethically and without liability. From my work in office settings, I have sharpened my organizational skills, attention to detail and my ability to work with speed and accuracy
cons: I can be very detailed at times...time consuming

pros: Strong work ethic from the associates. "Living our values" promoted frequently. Continuing education. Work / Life balance. Great benefits.
cons: Can be stressful at times to make a deadline no matter what the cost to the client. Understood management doesn't want to loose face with LOB but, pushing teams to deliver at all costs.

review_title: So burnt out, and it has only been 8 months
pros: competitive compensation and benefits plus paternity leave
cons: Overburdened workload, uncompetitive deposit and lending rates, a thankless job, not even enough in budget to purchase deposit slips and receipts for the customers.  There is a constant requirement to report productions so much so that it gets in the way of actually producing.  We do call nights now because everyone wants to leave the company because of some idiot's idea to have only one teller in the line.  Senior management doesn't have there finger in the pulse when it comes to the daily business of the branch.

job_title: Business Analyst Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The benefits weren't all bad. Good support team in the US to help you bridge what you don't get from offshore management.
cons:
Way too much job eliminations. Intellectual capital is no valued or appreciated . 
Worked for manager in another country, very disconnected from the teams until it's time to cut staff. Provided no opportunities for staff to find another job, once they make the decision you pretty much are gone the same day!.

pros: Work is interesting, and given free reign to be creative in your research and quantitative solutions. You can tell that your work has an effect on the business.
cons: There is a very high level of beaurocracy, and takes forever to get something done. Can be very competitive and hostile at times so if that bothers you could be uncomfortable. Also, underpaid for quants in job market.

pros: I worked for Bank of America for many years in business banking, retail banking, commercial banking and global banking.  It has great benefits and is a stable company.
cons: As associates leave, more work is expected of the remaining associates.  The goals put on associates are difficult to reach.  Poor work/life balance.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Mesa, AZ
pros: Stable company with good benefits.  They're not going out of business anytime soon, which is good to know I guess.
cons: They are behind the curve substantially with technology, both on the teller side as well as platform.  By far the worst training program for every level inside the banking center.  Sales and Customer Service strategy clash against each other.

review_title: The most stressful and horrifying experience of my professional career.
job_title: Vice President, Senior Audit Supervisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: The opportunity to gain a wide variety of business knowledge is endless.   The people outside of Audit are nice and professional.
cons: Your peers sell you down the river for their own mistakes trying to make you look bad deflection off their own performance issues.  The work week is 40 hours per week, but expectation is 50+ hours per week. People are jumping ship like flies and management is not hiring replacement, thus requiring longer work hours. The culture is to political and cut throat.

pros: As you expect from matured company, good processes in place for career development. Company invests a lot in employee learning and development, lot of opportunities if you are looking for a change. Competitive benefits
cons: If you are working in globally distributed teams work life balance could be a challenge. There is lot of work which does not allow time for personal life

review_title: No balance, but the benefits are amazing
job_title: Financial Center Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits are the best, and I've worked for major companies. Compensation is also high, bonuses are great if you can earn them.
cons: They almost brag about being short staffed. I haven't had a real lunch break in over 4 months (I'm salaried). My job is threatened on a regular basis. Too many chiefs, not enough Indians.

pros: Pay was generally good.  I did work with some very smart and hard-working people.
cons: There is too much an emphasis on changing roles every 2-3 years.  Additionally, the bank does not hire people to address busy times.  This creates some serious problems in completing work as many people are not fully trained while some positions may not be filled.

job_title: Relationship Manager in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Boa is working toward an employee friendly environment while also keeping up with competition. The bank is tough and competitive but if you are willing to work hard it is easy to succeed and promote.
cons: There are constant changes with management and  it is sometimes a challenge to figure out what the bank's priorities are.

pros: Get to work with a lot of really smart people that work hard to help customers with their financial needs. People are passionate about making processes and technology better.   Benefits are very good especially holiday/vacation/ 401k.
cons: There is always a lot of work to do. Must be comfortable with change. Leaders and processes can change frequently. Working in the financial industry (any financial institution) can be challenging. Until interest rates go up driving revenues, there will be constant pressure on the expense lines.

job_title: Small Business Specialist in Newark, DE
pros: paid vacation and sick time. location
cons: Over-worked and undervalued. Major discrepancy between pay with associates. Someone could start the same job you are doing tomorrow with no previous experience whats so ever and make 11 to 15 % percent more than you easily.

pros: Building and enhancing relationships with customers, working with amazing coworkers, awesome banking center manager. It's a good first job out of high school or if you want to get your footstep into the banking industry.
cons: Since you see the same customers daily, work can get repetitive. Not much growth in retail banking besides banker or banking center manager. If you like sales and customer service, it's a good job.

pros: Good benefits, many good people to work with.
cons: I worked in a call center as a customer service representative for the credit card division. You are a unit of production and as a typical large corporation they strive to keep costs as low as possible to maximize returns for the share holders. This means pay is kept as low as possible. It is routinely made clear you are replaceable.

pros: Very high level of talent, smart and great to work with for the most part.  Emphasis on management and leadership builds good teams and provides associates with opportunities to grow.
cons: Frequent change creates work environment that is transactional rather than strategic. Too much leadership and organizational change becomes frustrating for employees and makes it harder to build meaningful relationships, cultivate mentors, etc.

job_title: Senior Change Manager in Easton, PA
pros: Good work ethics, strong professionalism among technology teams. Good work life balance through opportunity for some positions to telecommute. Solid culture and values aligned with corporate code values and leadership model.
cons: Some teams have a feeling that enterprise policies either don't apply to them, or they don't appreciate the impact that changes made in their areas may impact other technologies. Work in progress.

review_title: Horrible, & scary experience at Bank of America..!!
pros: You get a paycheck every other week. And ok medical and dental benefits. Best part is when you get to leave, & go home.
cons: The managers don't know anything. Policies and procedures are too inconsistent. It's like they make them up as they go. Training is absolutely horrible. It's a complete joke. Bank of America has an extremely bad reputation for a reason. There are better companies to work for 1000%. Trust me! Don't work for Bank of America, you'll regret it. A complete waste of time.

pros: Attire is Casual dress; jeans, tee shirts,  sandals or sneakers allowed. Can wear shorts Fri. through Sun. Air conditioned, clean, polite culture.
cons: Very loud usually noisy, customer complaints on the amount of hold time are always the first item of discussion. A ot of turnaround, I have been there two years and less than five people remain from my training class of 24.

review_title: Horrible Environment, run for your life
pros: Benefits are great, that is the only pro about the company.
cons: Bank of America is a horrible place to work and I caution anyone that is trying to get hired by them for any position. I have had 3 bosses in two years and do not feel valued at my position at all.

pros: People are great, culture is really geared towards helping some of the junior analysts out,work life balance better than expected

job_title: Applications Support in New York, NY

Good Pay
Corporate Perks
Good health insurance package/401k

pros: Good/consistent training programs, easy to relocate with many branches nearby, employee perks, room for growth, one hour lunch, teller incentive

pros: The bank has a lot of talented associates, who generally work well together to achieve the bank's objectives.  The company has achieved well deserved acclaim for technological innovations designed to facilitate customer interaction with the bank.  The credit card and deposits side of the business appears to be a relatively stable and growing environment.
cons: Mortgage side of the business is shrinking.  Responsibility for certain support areas is rotated too often among process managers, which leads to a lack of in depth expertise in these areas.

pros:
Good Work/Life Balance
Professional Environment
Ability to quickly advance

Downsizing
Senior management is out of touch
You're nothing but a number to them

job_title: Sales Performance Manager in Jacksonville, FL

cons: Being part of a larger company presents challenges in certain areas.  One of which is the agility and nimbleness of the existing processes.  It is being addressed but at times feels to be moving slowly.

pros: Great benefits. Large organization with many different areas to explore. Great national presence with a well reputed brand. If willing to relocate there is a lot of expansion.
cons: Advancement can be based on who you know. Can be overlooked even with more than enough qualifications for a role if you haven't taken the exact path upper management wants. Salary can be on lower end in industry

pros: The benefits, regular paycheck and employee banking were all pretty awesome. Even the people you sit around can be great.

review_title: Great job to get your foot in the door into the financial sector.

Very male dominated culture.

pros: Good work environment. Competitive consumer and small business products.  Helpful staff, A variety of benefits. Many locations to choose from.  Solid bonus structure. Paid vacation.

pros: I've been with the company 8yrs and have literally held 5 different titles and now making 52% more than what I started out with. There is so much room for growth! This company has afforded me the opportunity to raise two kids comfortably! I'm forever grateful!

job_title: Senior Fraud Analyst in Dallas, TX

review_title: Good Benefits, Limited Staffing, Not Much Work Life Balance, Limited upward mobility outside of the branches.

review_title: I have worked other places where you are actually treated with respect.

job_title: Banking Center Manager in Chicago, IL

review_title: Great workplace environment working with good people.

pros: Great benefits, Hours, pay is decent if your young & single living with your parents rent free. flexible schedules. management is pretty cool.

review_title: It's so big it's like working for the government of a small country, politics included.

review_title: very good company with very low turnover which says a lot

Soon you realize if it sounds too good to be true... it is probably Merrill Edge! Also... you get 4 weeks vacation and 2 weeks sick time, that is decent.
cons: Everything! Their systems are beyond old and you have absolutely no support! If you come from a real firm... you will not be able to handle the amount of "hand holding". You can't place a trade over 25k without prior approval, you can't place sells without prior approval. You pretty much need prior approval to do anything! It is like they punish you for actually trying to do your job by making it beyond difficult to place any trades. They push their own managed product that has a horrible track record. You need to challenge everything you do to get your bonus for it. You will spend more time doing bank products, like credit cards, issuing debit cards,service, printing statements than you will doing investments or advising. Management... oh dear is that another story! Management is people who have NEVER had experience in the field. They promote people from the bank side who have only banking experience and they expect them to be able to manage investment advisors. They promote the wrong people and don't focus on what is important... the  client! This entire organization needs to be reevaluated and redesigned. Mostly... large layoffs and replaced by quality employees!

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
You can work as a home office fsa by phone in a regional center or as a field based fsa at a local BofA. There are multiple teams at the home office with different jobs but in the field there’s only the field fsa (not counting the gwim roles like bfa). Most reviews are for either of these positions, but I’ve done both roles, & over a year’s time in each. I worked on different home office teams when I was at the center, and since moving to the field at a local BofA I worked at 2 centers before resigning. I have Merrill top performer  “bulls” and I’ve also been on written warning. I’ve experienced this role inside & out.

Pros: all from the center. Coming licensed and with phone sales experience I started on a well paid team with no adherence and only talking to people interested in investing with Edge. Bonuses even after cuts were ok, 401k match after a year, & annual contribution that vests after 3 yrs, paid time off, vacation, several health plan choices. Most new employees  get stuck on inbound service teams listening to complaints all day. I lucked out because of my prior experience & licensing.  After a year and working on 2 different teams at the center I transferred to the field fsa role.
cons:
Cons: all from the field fsa role. You’re just a licensed banker, like most other reviews state. Especially since adoption to DOL ruling removed everything an fsa can do on the investment side except open online accounts,  refer to Merrill Lynch, or enroll in Merrill Edge Select Portfolios, and if you do that, once enrolled the reviews are all done by a home office team. That means no relationship for you to build on with any of these options, b/c compliance prohibits field fsa’s from proactively calling on these clients.

Most of your day is spent doing banking, and sadly, the fsa is pressured  to get more bank referrals, “present” credit card offers, and open new deposit accounts. Any Merrill Edge business is a one time transaction, you don’t build a book and don’t build a relationship either. The msm is just a policeman who's job it is to make sure you are hitting the numbers,  issue warnings, or fire you if you don’t make the unrealistic metrics. No positive coaching, like discussions  about long term career goals after the fsa role. Constant micromanaging to make sure recorded calls are done daily, bank products have been offered to everyone to sit with, and overall the fsa is treated like an entry level banker on their first job right out of college. Not to mention constant pressure to sell MESP, which is garbage and clients (along with many people at the firm, too) know it. Since BofA chose to realign the fsa to consumer banking from wealth management, it was also decided at that time to essentially treat us like bankers and not like financial advisors anymore. 

Most msm’s don't how each bank is in a different city, demographic, and the foot traffic is different. BofA keeps pushing people to do everything online, on the app, or at the atm to reduce costs but keeps insisting its realistic to expect each fsa at any center to consistently see 5 to 7 people per day. 

Compliance is a nightmare having to deal with it both from BofA and Merrill Edge. You have to know how to open, process, and service both BofA and Merrill Edge/Lynch accounts, which can take a while to learn. Even though I was an internal transfer, training for the fsa role was a joke and all I learned was how not to get in trouble on the bank side, & hardly any time was spent on investment training, knowledge, and how to be a successful financial advisor.  Having to track your own compensation is awful, and you often must challenge to ensure you are given proper credit.

job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros:
Benefits
Pay for your licenses
Good way to get your foot into the industry
cons:
Micromanaged - Every single minute of your day is scheduled and planned out.  Every action you do on the computer is recorded and monitored.  Not on a call for 15 minutes because you are doing call work?  Expect to get an email from your manager asking what is wrong.  On call and you go 20 minutes over when you are supposed to take lunch? You better cut that out!  Try to imagine doing that 9 hours a day.  Every, single, day!

Glorified banker - You are a "financial advisor" but the only advising you can do is either open a none-advised self-direct account, or into a "robo advised" product where the financial advisor aspect is taken out. Thats right, you can NOT recommend a product where you are involved.  Try convincing clients to move their accounts over when you tell them that.

Regulations to the max - To verify a client you have to verify FIVE PIECES OF INFORMATION.  Try doing that at the start of a conversation and going anywhere with it.  Any time investments are brought up you have to read a paragraph disclosure.  Im not joking, its a paragraph!  Any time you do a "review" with the client you have to touch on multiple financial terms and make sure the client fully understands. You can already picture the reaction when you try explaining multiple financial terms to a discount brokerage client, who you will be lucky if they even have heard of a mutual fund.

Archaic Systems-  They are too cheap to update their software.  You will be using systems from 1999 to document every single one of your calls. They are too cheap to invest into salesforce.  Maybe they just like the software because it seems to "forget" to credit you for half of your paid out metrics, forcing you to document, monitor, and keep track of every single potential payout.  Seems easy enough, but when you are doing 25-35 calls with clients every day it can get hard to keep track of.  Especially with the 100 other items you are being micro managed on.

I could go on and on about this job and how terrible it was. You will find the only people who are staying at Merrill Edge are single parents, people over 50 who can not get a job anywhere else in the finance industry, people without college degrees, or candidates straight out of college.  They prey upon the weak knowing this is your only option.   I was a very positive and happy person before this job, but during it I was beyond depressed.  Thankfully I had my degree, did my year, and GOT OUT!

review_title: Premium Elite Relationship Manager - Low point in my life
job_title: Premium Elite Relationship Manager in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Compensation is pretty fair and free food around tax season.
cons:
Being a call center rep at a low-tier online broker is horrible. If you're not trying to solve some paperwork issue, you might be getting screamed at because the company you work for sucks. Here is my list of questions that any prospective rep needs to ask at their interview.
Q:"How many of my conversations will be with clients that have transferable assets?"
A "Very few, most of your time will be spent with some of our day traders calculating buying power by hand, or with clients that have other assets at Merrill Lynch or already have everything here. So your time won't be spent on improving your bonus."
Q: "What happens if one of my assigned clients closes their account?"
A: " We take $$$ from your bonus. We don't care if you have never spoken to the person...it's your fault."
Q: "Do people enjoy working here?"
A: "Everyone hates it here, everyone is underemployed, everyone is embarrassed by what they do. Our first team in Rolling Meadows had 3 people quit in their first 9 months.
Q: "What is the vacation policy?"
A:  " We do give you a fair amount of days off. Pretty much no chance you'll ever get a Friday (you have to use you sick days) and no way you'll ever get a day before a bank holiday."
Q "How is management?"
A: " When of our leaders comes to the office, everyone is required to wear suits. The managers don't speak to anyone on the team and just hide in their offices."
Q: " How are our calls monitored?"
A: " There is a dedicated team that will do everything possible to fail you. These low scores directly impact your bonus."
Q: "What skills will I learn?"
A: "Everything you'll learn is only specific to Merrill Edge. So your experience here won't help you at all. And on top of that, you'll have to explain why you took a service role at a call center."
Q: "I was told that top reps have quarterly bonuses of 30K and higher. Is this true?"
A "Lol!"

Please don't waste any moments of your life in this role. Every day here is bad. You will learn nothing. The environment is toxic. Management will lie to get you in the door. There are far far batter ways to spend your life....don't do it.

review_title: Ethics will go out the window
job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros:
- Get a paycheck to help with bills
- Licenses will be active
- Learn how Merrill operates so you can compare to other brokerage firms
cons:
- Ethical behavior will put you at a disadvantage for growth opportunities
- Like any company they will have signs all over the place hinting at ethical behavior, doing what's right for the client. However, you will learn quickly that to get ahead at Merrill Edge you will need to provide shady if not downright unethical advice to clients.
- If you are like me you have a Series 7 (and other licenses) for at least a decade and worked at various brokerage firms. After working for Merrill I realize how awesome some of my previous employers were. I do regret moving to Merrill and am now just 'cruising' by until the economy picks up a bit. 
- Merrill Edge, not Merrill Lynch, is a call center type environment. Just like a Schwab, Vanguard, or other similar brokerage firm. 
- Management goes around yelling at reps throughout the day. If your manager needs to talk to you about something they do it in front of the entire floor so everyone knows what is going on. There is no career advancement discussions or one-on-one's with your management team.
- VP's just sit in their office all day collecting a big paycheck as you slave away. They do not address concerns of employees. They do not talk to you. 
- To get ahead, you will need to lie, cheat and steal. Management and Compliance will turn a blind eye so if you didn't attend ethics class in college and you don't mind doing what's wrong to get ahead, you will go far- unless they find a reason to not like you and then they will use the unethical behavior to fire you
- Basically, it's like making a deal with the devil
